ADOPTING ORDINANCES



ORDINANCE NO. 83-15



   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING A REVISION, CODIFICATION, AND RECODIFICATION OF
THE ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF FRANKFORT, INDIANA



   BE IT ORDAINED, by the Common Council of the City of Frankfort, Indiana
as follows:



   1.   The ordinances of the City of Frankfort of a permanent nature,
as revised, amended, restated, codified and recodified in the following Title
1 through Title 15, inclusive, which are hereby incorporated by reference and
two copies of which are on file with the City Clerk-Treasurer for public
inspection are hereby adopted as "THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF THE CITY OF
FRANKFORT, 1983".



   2.   THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF THE CITY OF FRANKFORT, 1983 is hereby
ordered to be published in book or pamphlet form pursuant to I.C.
36-4-6-14(c).  Publication shall be made by delivering copies of THE
MUNICIPAL CODE OF FRANKFORT, 1983 for public inspection and use at the
following locations:



                  The Frankfort Public Library



                  The Office of the City Engineer



                  The Office of the City Attorney



                  The Office of the City Clerk-Treasurer



                  The Office of the Mayor



                  The Library of the Clinton Circuit Court



                  The Frankfort Police Station



                  The Frankfort Fire Department



THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF FRANKFORT, 1983 or any portion thereof shall also be
made available to the general public upon payment of the City of Frankfort's
actual expense of providing said Code.



   3.   THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF THE CITY OF FRANKFORT, 1983 shall be in
full force and effect two weeks after its adoption and publication.



   Passed by the Common Council of the City of Frankfort, Indiana this 9th
day of January, 1984.

ORDINANCE NO. CO 89-7



   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF
ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF FRANKFORT, INDIANA



   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio
completed the 1989 S-6 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Frankfort, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this
municipality; and



   WHEREAS, said American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the
revision or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are
based on or make references to sections of the Indiana Code; and



   WHEREAS, it is the intent of Council to accept these updated sections
in accordance with the changes of the law of the State of Indiana;



   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Common Council of the City of
Frankfort, State of Indiana;



   SECTION I:  That the 1989 S-6 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of
the City of Frankfort as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation
of Cincinnati, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.



   SECTION II:  That this ordinance shall take effect and be in force
from and after its date of passage.



   ADOPTED this 26th day of June, 1989.



   Don E. Snyder /s/             



   President of the Common Council



ATTEST: Marilyn Chittick /s/   



        Secretary, Common Council



   Presented by me to the Mayor of the City of Frankfort, Indiana, for
approval and signature, this 26th day of June, 1989, at 8:10 p.m.



   Marilyn K. Chittick /s/



   City Clerk-Treasurer 



   Approved and signed by me, this 26th day of June, 1989, at 8:10 p.m.



   Don E. Snyder /s/               



   Mayor, City of Frankfort, Indiana

§ 10.01  TITLE OF CODE.



   This codification of ordinances by and for the City of Frankfort,
Indiana, shall be designated as the "Code of the City of Frankfort, Indiana,"
and may be so cited.



('75 Code, § 1.01)



§ 10.02  INTERPRETATION.



   (A)   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication
required, the same rules of construction, definition, and application shall
govern the interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation
of the Indiana  Code.



   (B)   Where a section of this code is followed by a reference to the
Indiana Code, the reference indicates the section is analogous or similar to
the cited sections in the Indiana Code.  Footnotes, cross references, and
other comments are by way of explanation only and should not be deemed a part
of the text of any section.



   (C)   All provisions of this code are limited in application to the
territorial boundaries of the municipal corporation although they may not be
so limited specifically.



§ 10.03  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this code the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AND or OR.  AND may be read OR and OR may be AND if the sense requires
it.



   CITY.  The City of Frankfort, Clinton County, Indiana.



   THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES.  The municipal code as modified
by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.



   COUNCIL.  The Common Council of Frankfort, Indiana.



   COUNTY.  Clinton County, Indiana.



   MAY.  The act referred to is permissive.



   MONTH.  A calendar month.



   OATH.  An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation
may be substituted for an oath, and in those cases the words  SWEAR and
SWORN shall be equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.



   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT. An officer,
office, employee, commission, or department of the city unless the context
clearly requires otherwise.



   OWNER.  When applied to a building or land, OWNER shall include any
part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint
tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of the building
or land.



   OCCUPANT.  See TENANT or OCCUPANT.



   PERSON.  Includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, trustee, or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.



   PERSONAL PROPERTY.  Every species of property except real property.



   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING.  Next before or next after, respectively.



   PROPERTY.  Real and personal property.



   PUBLIC PLACE.  Any street or highway, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, or open space adjacent thereto and any lake or stream.



   REAL PROPERTY.  Lands, tenements, and hereditaments and all chattels
real.



   REASONABLE TIME.  In all cases where any provision shall require any
act to be done in a REASONABLE TIME or REASONABLE NOTICE is to be given to
any person, the reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean that time
only as may be necessary in the prompt execution of the duty, or compliance
with the notice.



   SHALL.  The act referred to is mandatory.



   SIDEWALK.  That portion of a street between the curb lines of the
lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the
use of pedestrians.



   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION.  Includes a mark when the person cannot
write.



   STATE.  State of Indiana.



   STREET.  Streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, viaducts, and
all other public highways in the city.



   SUBCHAPTER.  A division of a chapter, designated in this code by an
underlined heading in the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the
body of the chapter, setting apart a group of sections related by the subject
matter of the heading.  Not all chapters have subchapters.



   TENANT or OCCUPANT.  Applied to a building or land, shall include any
person holding a written or oral lease, or who occupies the whole or a part
of the building or land, either alone or with others.



   WRITTEN.  Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.



   YEAR.  A calendar year.



('75 Code, § 1.04)



§ 10.04  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.



   The construction of all ordinances of this city shall be by the
following rules, unless such a construction is plainly repugnant to the
intent of the legislative body or of the context of the ordinance.



   (A)   Acts by assistants.  When a statute requires an act to be
done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, such
a requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of the act by an
authorized agent or deputy.



   (B)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses.  Words denoting the
masculine gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders;
words in the singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall
include the singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include
the future, if applicable.



   (C)   General term.  A general term following  specific
enumeration of terms is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless
expressly so limited.



   (D)   Joint authority.  Words importing joint authority to three or
more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of those persons,
unless otherwise declared in the law giving the authority.



   (E)   Computation of time.  The time within which an act is to be
done, as herein provided, shall be computed by excluding the first day and
including the last.  If the last day is Sunday, it shall be excluded.



('75 Code, § 1.04)



§ 10.05  CAPTIONS.



   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter,
and section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.



('75 Code, § 1.03)



§ 10.06  APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.



   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation, shall
apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code
unless otherwise specifically provided.



§ 10.07  REFERENCES TO OTHER SECTIONS.



   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof,
the reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as
subsequently amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject
matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.



§ 10.08  REFERENCES TO OFFICES.



   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of the municipality exercising the powers,
duties, or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any
transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.



§ 10.09  OFFENSES PUNISHABLE UNDER SEPARATE PROVISIONS.



   In all cases where the same offenses may be made punishable or may be
created by different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting
officer may elect under which to proceed.  However, not more than one
recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense, except
where continuing acts are designated in the code as separate offenses.



('75 Code, § 1.05)



§ 10.10  SUBJECTS COVERED UNDER STATE LAW.



   All other matters concerning municipal government not specifically
mentioned in this code shall be governed by the relevant provisions of state
law applicable to municipal government.



('75 Code, § 1.06)



§ 10.11  RECORDING AND PUBLICATION OF ORDINANCES.



   All ordinances passed by the Common Council shall be recorded by the
Clerk-Treasurer in a book of ordinances.  The due proof of publication of
all ordinances requiring publication by affidavit of the printer or publisher
shall be procured by the Clerk-Treasurer and maintained in the office of the
Clerk-Treasurer.



('75 Code, § 1.09)



Statutory reference:



   Publication of ordinances, see I.C. 36-4-6-14



   Recording ordinances, see I.C. 36-4-6-17



§ 10.12  EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.



   All ordinances passed by the Common Council requiring publication shall
take effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise
expressly provided.  Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect
from their passage, and upon being signed and attested to, unless otherwise
expressly provided.



('75 Code, § 1.10)



§ 10.13  REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.



   (A)   Any ordinance or part of an ordinance repealed or modified by
a subsequent ordinance shall continue in force until the publication of the
subsequent ordinance, when publication is required to give effect thereto. 
When publication is not required, the repealing or modifying ordinance shall
take effect immediately upon passage, unless expressly provided otherwise.



   (B)   No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty
instituted, created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous
to its repeal shall in anywise be affected, released, or discharged, but may
be prosecuted, enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had
continued in force unless it is otherwise expressly provided.



('75 Code, § 1.11)



   (C)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or
provision shall be itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to
revive the former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly
provided.  ('75 Code, § 1.12)



§ 10.14  ORDINANCES REPEALED.



   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated
and embraced.  All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by
this code shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this
code.



('75 Code, § 1.02)



§ 10.15  ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.



   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other
ordinances pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in
full force and effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary
implication.



('75 Code, § 1.02)



§ 10.16  ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.



   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention
of the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning
can be attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was
clearly intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and
the word or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the
manifest intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though
the correct words were contained in the text as originally published.  No
alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the
nature or extent of any error.



§ 10.17  SEVERABILITY.



   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its
application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity
does not affect other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid
provision or application.



('75 Code, § 1.07)



§ 10.99  GENERAL PENALTY.



   Wherever in this code or in any ordinances of the city, or rule or
regulation promulgated by an officer or agency thereof, under authority
vested by law or ordinance, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to
be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is required, or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty
is provided therefor, the violation of those provisions of this code,
ordinance, rule, or regulation, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding
$500. Every day any violation of this code or any ordinance, rule, or
regulation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.



('75 Code, § 1.08)

CHAPTER 30:  EXECUTIVE BRANCH



Section



   30.01   General city government organization



   30.02   Mayor as head of executive branch



   30.03   Board of Public Works and Safety; control of certain
executive departments



   30.04   Department of Law



   30.05   Department of Planning and Zoning Appeals and Economic
Development



   30.06   Department of Utilities



   30.07   Appointment of various city employees, department heads



   30.08   Authority to hire employees; appropriation powers of city
departments



§ 30.01  GENERAL CITY GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATION.



   The government of the city shall consist of five branches, those being:



   (A)   Executive branch   (I.C. 36-4-5-1 et seq.).



   (B)   Legislative branch   (I.C. 36-4-6-1 et seq.).



   (C)   Fiscal branch      (I.C. 36-4-10-1 et seq.).



   (D)   Judicial branch.



   (E)   Statutory boards and commissions.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.02  MAYOR AS HEAD OF EXECUTIVE BRANCH.



   The Mayor is the City Executive and head of the executive branch.  He
or she shall faithfully perform the duties and responsibilities contained in
I.C. 36-4-5-1 et seq. and other statutes of the state.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.03  BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY; CONTROL OF CERTAIN EXECUTIVE
DEPARTMENTS.



   (A)   There is hereby established a Board of Public Works and Safety
within the executive branch.



   (B)   The Board shall be the chief administrative body of the city
and shall have control of the day-to- day operations of the following
executive departments which are hereby established:



      (1)   Police Department.



      (2)   Fire Department.



      (3)   Street and Sanitation Department.



      (4)   Park and Recreation Department.



      (5)   Civil Defense Department.



      (6)   Engineer and Building Inspector Department.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.04  DEPARTMENT OF LAW.



   There is hereby established a Department of Law pursuant to I.C.
36-4-9-12.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.05  DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND ZONING APPEALS AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT.



   (A)   There is hereby established a Department of Planning and
Zoning Appeals and Economic Development.



   (B)   The Department shall consist of two divisions:



      (1)   Planning and Zone Appeals organized under I.C. 36-7.



      (2)   Economic Development Commission organized under I.C.
36-7.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.06  DEPARTMENT OF UTILITIES.



   There is hereby established a Department of Utilities organized under
I.C. 8-1.5.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 30.07  APPOINTMENT OF VARIOUS CITY EMPLOYEES, DEPARTMENT HEADS.



   (A)   The members of the Board of Public Works and Safety are the
Mayor and other members who shall be chosen by the Mayor and who shall serve
at his or her pleasure.  The Chiefs of the Police and Fire Departments are
appointed by the Mayor and shall serve at his or her pleasure, in accordance
with I.C. 36- 4-9.



   (B)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-4-9-2, the Mayor shall appoint the other
heads of the departments, including the Municipal Utilities, with the
approval of the statutory board or commission operating the department if
such exist.  The statutory boards and commissions, including the Utility
Service Board, shall give notice to the Mayor and the appropriate
councilmanic committee of all meetings or hearings, whether or not conducted
in executive session, which concern any merit rating, job performance
evaluation, salary review, disciplinary proceeding, or termination proceeding
and which relate to any department head.  The Mayor and the appropriate
councilmanic committee shall be entitled to attend any such meeting or
hearing whether or not conducted in executive session and address the
statutory board or commission.



   (C)   All appointed heads of the city departments, including the
Chief of the City Police Department and the Chief of the City Fire
Department, shall be residents of Clinton County, Indiana.



   (D)   All future appointees of the Park and Street Departments shall
be residents of the city.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-82-19, passed 1l-22-82; Am. Ord.
17-20, passed 10-23-17)



§ 30.08  AUTHORITY TO HIRE EMPLOYEES; APPROPRIATION POWERS OF CITY
DEPARTMENTS.



   (A)   Subject to the appropriation power of the Common Council, the
foregoing Departments discussed in §§  30.01 through 30.07, except the
Utilities Department, shall have the ability to hire any employees, and
purchase or contract for those materials or services, as the Board of Works
and Safety or other governing board or commission deems necessary to perform
their public functions.



   (B)   The Utilities Department shall be subject to the jurisdiction
and appropriation powers of the City Utility Service Board as set out in I.C.
8-1.5-3.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)

ORGANIZATION



§ 31.01  COMMON COUNCIL AS CITY LEGISLATIVE BRANCH.



   The legislative branch of the city is the Common Council.  The Council
shall have exclusive authority to adopt ordinances and appropriate tax monies
received by the city, and to perform other necessary and desirable
legislative functions.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



Statutory reference:



   City legislative bodies, see I.C. 36-4-6-1 et seq.



§ 31.02  ELECTION, NUMBER OF COUNCIL MEMBERS.



   The Common Council shall be composed of seven members, five of whom are
elected from districts and two of whom are elected at large.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.03  CLERK-TREASURER AS CLERK OF COUNCIL.



   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be the Clerk of the Council and shall perform
the duties prescribed by I.C. 36-4-6-9 and such others as the Council may
direct.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.04  REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS.



   (A)   The regular meeting date, time and place for the Common
Council shall be 7:00 p.m. (EST) on the second Monday of each month, in the
Council Chambers located in the City Building, 301 E. Clinton Street
Frankfort, Indiana.



   (B)   Special meetings shall be held on the call of the Mayor or
upon the written request of four members of the Council.  Such special
meetings shall be held on the 4th Monday of each month.  EXCEPT in the case
of an EMERGENCY the Mayor may set the meeting for any weekday after giving
proper notice.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-95-1, passed 4-3-95)



§ 31.05  PRESIDING OFFICER; PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE.



   (A)   The Mayor of the city shall be the Presiding Officer of the
Common Council.  The Mayor shall be designated as the President of the
Common Council.



   (B)   In the absence of the Mayor, a President Pro-Tempore shall be
the Presiding Officer of the Common Council, and except as otherwise provided
herein, he or she shall have the same powers and duties while presiding as
the President.  The President Pro-Tempore shall be chosen from the members
of the Common Council; at the first meeting, or anytime thereafter, of each
year, the Council shall elect one of its members for this position, and he or
she shall hold the position of President Pro-Tempore through December 31 of
that year.  Until a President Pro-Tempore is chosen as set out above, at any
meeting from which the Mayor is absent, the Council shall choose one of its
members to preside as President Pro- Tempore at that meeting only.  At a
meeting from which both the President and President Pro-Tempore are absent,
the Council shall choose one of its members to preside as President
Pro-Tempore at that meeting only.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.06  QUORUM.



   A majority of all the members-elect shall constitute a quorum, and it
shall require a majority vote of all the members-elect to pass an ordinance.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



RULES OF PROCEDURE



§ 31.15  AUTHORITY OF PRESIDENT OF COUNCIL.



   (A)   The President shall chair the meeting of the Council and shall
promptly call the members to order at 7:00 p.m. (EST).



   (B)   He or she shall preserve strict order and decorum in the
Council.



   (C)   He or she shall appoint all committees.



   (D)   He or she shall not vote on any question except in case of a
tie vote.



   (E)   He or she shall pronounce the decision of the Council on all
subjects, and decide questions of order without debate, subject to an appeal
to the Council by any two members.  When so demanded, the President shall
put the question of appeal to the Council in the following general form: 
"Shall the decision of the chair stand as the decision of the Council?",
whereupon the City Clerk-Treasurer shall call the roll of the members for a
vote.  If a majority vote "aye", the decision of the chair shall stand;
otherwise, the appeal shall be sustained.  Anything herein to the contrary
notwithstanding, the President Pro-Tempore shall have the right to vote on
all matters, the same as any other member, but the President Pro-Tempore
shall not have the right to cast an extra vote in the case of a tie vote.



   (F)   The Mayor (i.e. the President of Council) shall have the right
to offer recommendations to the Council, and he or she shall have the right
without relinquishing the chair, to speak on any question and to take part in
any debate.  While participating in any debate, he or she shall be subject
to the rules governing the Council.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-95-1, passed 4-3-95)



§ 31.16  VOTING; TIE VOTES AND ROLL-CALL VOTES.



   Except as otherwise provided in these rules, the President shall state
all questions fully and distinctly to the Council, and shall decide whether
the questions are carried by an affirmative or negative vote.  However, if
the vote is a tie or if a decision is called for by any member of the
Council, the Council shall decide by a roll-call vote, and the City
Clerk-Treasurer shall make the count.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



Cross-reference:



   Voting by President of Council, or by President Pro Tempore of Council,
see §  31.15



§ 31.17  RECONSIDERATION OF VOTE.



   Any member of the Council who voted with the majority may call for a
reconsideration of any vote at the same meeting of the Council at which it
passed, and if sustained by a majority of the votes, the reconsideration
shall be carried.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.18  MOTIONS, RESOLUTIONS, AND ORDINANCES.



   (A)   No motion shall be subject to debate until it has been
seconded and stated by the President.  It shall be reduced to writing upon
the demand of the President or any member.  After a motion has been stated
by the President, it shall be deemed to be in possession of the Council, and
it may be withdrawn by the mover at any time before the decision or
amendment, with the permission of the Council member who seconded the motion.



   (B)   It shall not be necessary to have more than one reading of a
resolution or other motion, except an ordinance.  After the resolution or
other motion has been read or made and before a vote has been taken thereon,
the President may refer the same to a standing Council committee for its
study and recommendation, unless a majority of the Council present determines
that action by the Council shall be taken at that meeting.  If such a
determination is made, then the Council may act upon the resolution or other
motion in any manner that it can otherwise act, including but not limited to
passing, rejecting, amending, or committing the resolution or other motion. 
The motion that the Council take action on the resolution or other motion at
that meeting is not debatable or referable to committee and must be put to a
vote immediately.



   (C)   Every proposed ordinance shall receive three readings in open
Council, each reading being on a different day, unless upon motion the
Council determines by unanimous vote, with not less than a majority of the
members-elect present and voting, that the rules be suspended for the purpose
of taking action on two or three readings at the same meeting.



      (1)   Except as otherwise provided in these rules, upon the
first reading of an ordinance no motion shall be in order except a motion to
pass the ordinance on first reading or to reject the ordinance.  If the
ordinance is passed upon first reading, the President may refer the proposed
ordinance to a standing Council committee for its study and recommendation. 
If the President does not assign the proposed ordinance to a committee, a
majority of the Council present may require the President to make such an
assignment.



      (2)   Upon the second reading of any ordinance, the ordinance
shall be read by title only, unless a reading in full is requested by a
member of the Council.  The only motions in order upon a second reading are
as follows.



         (a)   To commit.



         (b)   To amend.



         (c)   To lay on the table.



         (d)   To postpone to a certain time.



         (e)   To postpone indefinitely (should an ordinance be
postponed indefinitely, it shall not be again taken up prior to the next
regular Council meeting).



         (f)   To pass on second reading.



      (3)   Except as otherwise provided herein, upon the third
reading of any ordinance, it shall be read in full.  By a unanimous vote of
the members present at a meeting of the Council, an ordinance upon first or
third reading may be read by title only, and the reading shall be considered
to be a full and complete reading of the ordinance.  The vote on the third
reading of an ordinance shall be by calling the roll and recording the "aye"
and "no" votes.  Any member or the President may demand a roll call vote be
taken on any other question or motion, and when so taken the question or
motion shall be so put on the record.



   (D)   Further action by the Council on any proposed ordinance,
resolution, or other matter referred to a committee shall not be taken until
the committee reports back to the Council at a regular or special meeting;
however, a majority of the Council present may cause the postponed ordinance,
resolution, or other matter to be taken from the committee and placed before
the Council for its consideration.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-88-2, passed 2-22-88)



§ 31.19  MEMBER CALLED TO ORDER.



   If a member of the Council shall, while speaking, be called to order by
the President, he/she shall cease speaking and take his/her seat until the
question of order is determined and permission is given to speak.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.20  ADDRESSING COUNCIL.



   No one who is not a member of the Council shall be permitted to address
Council except by request or consent of the President.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.21  COMMITTEES.



   (A)   The members of the Council's committees shall be selected from
the members of the Council, and shall consist of not less than three members
each.  The committees shall be appointed annually and shall hold such
positions through the end of the particular calendar year.



   (B)   The standing committees shall be as follows:



      (1)   Committee on Utilities.



      (2)   Committee on Police.



      (3)   Committee on Fire.



      (4)   Committee on Streets, Alleys and Sewers.



      (5)   Committee on Parks.



      (6)   Committee on Finance.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-95-1, passed 4-3-95)



§ 31.22  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.



   Except when in conflict with permission of these rules, Robert's Rules
of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern all proceedings of the Council.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 31.23  AMENDING RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   These rules shall be suspended, amended, rescinded, or otherwise
changed only by the adoption of an ordinance for that purpose.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)

§ 31.31  REDISTRICTING.



   City Ordinance (82-14) provides that redistricting shall be made every
ten years as provided by the State Code reported in I.C. 36-4-6-4 and I.C.
36-4-6-5.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-95-1, passed 4-3-95; Am. Ord.
02-15, passed 7-22-02)



CHAPTER 32:  FISCAL BRANCH



Section



   32.01   Clerk-Treasurer as head of fiscal branch



   32.02   Deputy Clerk-Treasurers



   32.03   Utility clerks



Cross-reference:



   City government, general organization of, see §  30.01



§ 32.01  CLERK-TREASURER AS HEAD OF FISCAL BRANCH.



   The Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the city and the head of
the fiscal branch.  He or she shall perform the duties assigned by I.C.
36-4-10-1 et seq. and such other duties as the Common Council may, by
ordinance, require.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 32.02  DEPUTY CLERK-TREASURERS.



   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized, pursuant to I.C. 36-4-11-4,
to appoint two Deputy Clerk- Treasurers, one to be paid solely from funds
appropriated for the office of Clerk-Treasurer, and one to be paid from funds
appropriated for the office of Clerk-Treasurer and other funds for whom the
Clerk-Treasurer provides services.  The Deputies shall work under the
exclusive direction of the Clerk-Treasurer, and serve at the pleasure of the
Clerk-Treasurer.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 32.03  UTILITY CLERKS.



   The various utility clerks needed to manage the bookkeeping and
administrative requirements of the utilities shall be appointed and
compensated by the board having control of the utility the clerk serves. 
The utility clerks serve at the pleasures of the board which appointed
them.  The Clerk-Treasurer and the Mayor shall be compensated for services
he or she renders to the city's utilities.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



CHAPTER 33:  JUDICIAL BRANCH



Section



   33.01   Establishment of city court; City Judge



Cross-reference:



   City government, general organization of, see §  30.01



§ 33.01  ESTABLISHMENT OF CITY COURT; CITY JUDGE.



   There is hereby established, effective January 1, 1984, a city court,
to be headed and operated by a City Judge elected and seated pursuant to I.C.
33-35-1.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



CHAPTER 34:  STATUTORY BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS



Section



   34.01   Police Pension Board of Trustees



   34.02   Firefighters' Pension Board of Trustees



   34.03   Utility Service Board



   34.04   Aviation Authority Board



   34.05   Redevelopment Commission



   34.06   Ordinance Violations Bureau



Cross-reference:



   City government, general organization of, see §  30.01



§ 34.01  POLICE PENSION BOARD OF TRUSTEES.



   There shall be a Police Pension Board of Trustees to perform certain
duties prescribed by I.C. 36-8-6 (1925 Fund) and I.C. 36-8-8 (1977 Fund)
concerning the statutory pensions of city police.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 34.02  FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION BOARD OF TRUSTEES.



   There shall be a Firefighters' Pension Board of Trustees to perform
certain duties prescribed by I.C. 36-8-7 (1937 Fund) and I.C. 36-8-8 (1977
Fund) concerning the statutory pensions of city firefighters.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 34.03  UTILITY SERVICE BOARD.



   (A)   There is a Utility Service Board to perform the duties
prescribed by I.C. 8-1.5-3 concerning the statutory responsibilities of
operating the electric utility, water utility, and the wastewater treatment
plant and collection systems of the city.



   (B)   The Board shall be composed of five members, not more than a
majority of whom shall be members of the same political party. Each member
appointed shall be a resident of Clinton County, Indiana, and shall also
reside within the area served by any of the utility services which are under
the control of the Utility Service Board. No member of the Board shall be an
employee or officer of any public utility and no member shall hold any other
elected public office while serving as a member of the Board. Each member
shall take and subscribe an oath of office upon such member’s appointment
to the Board.



   (C)   All powers and duties associated with the construction,
improvement, operation, maintenance and management of the city's storm sewer
system is hereby transferred to the Utility Service Board of the city;
provided that all rates, fees or regulations established by the Board with
regard to such storm sewers must receive approval by the Common Council.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82; Am. Ord. CO-05-10, passed 10-24-05; Am. Ord.
12-03A, passed 3-12-12)



§ 34.04  AVIATION AUTHORITY BOARD.



   There is an Aviation Authority Board to perform the duties prescribed
by I.C. 8-22-3 concerning the statutory responsibilities of operating the
airport of the city.



(Ord. CO-82-14, passed 8-30-82)



§ 34.05  REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.



   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-14-3, the Council hereby establishes the
City of Frankfort Department of Redevelopment (the “Department”), for the
purposes and to exercise the powers set forth in I.C. 36-7-14 and I.C.
36-7-25 (collectively, the “Act”) or otherwise granted by law. The
Department will be controlled by, and the Common Council hereby
reestablishes, a board of five members to be known as the City of Frankfort
Redevelopment Commission (the “Redevelopment Commission”), two of whom
shall be appointed by the Council and three of whom shall be appointed by the
Mayor of the city. Each member of the Redevelopment Commission must be at
least 18 years of age, and must be a resident of the city.



   (B)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-14-6.1, the Mayor of the city shall
appoint an individual to serve as a nonvoting advisor to the Redevelopment
Commission who must be a member of the school board of a school corporation
that includes all or a part of the territory served by the Redevelopment
Commission.



(Ord. 12-02, passed 2-13-12)



§ 34.06  ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS BUREAU.



   (A)   There is hereby created an Ordinance Violations Bureau for the
city and the Clerk-Treasurer shall serve as Administrator and Violations
Clerk of the Bureau.



   (B)   The Violations Clerk may accept written appearances, waivers
of trial, admissions of violations, and payment of civil penalties of not
more than $250 in ordinance violation cases.



   (C)   Notwithstanding other provisions as to civil penalties that
exist throughout the Municipal Code of the City of Frankfort, the offender
may, prior to the initial hearing, admit said violation before the Violations
Clerk and pay civil penalty according to the following schedule.



 

City Code Section
 
Violation
 
Civil Penalty Amount




Chapters 71 and 78
 
Traffic Rules and Regulations
 
$30    (first offense)


Mopeds
 
$60   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$90   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)


Chapters 72 and 73
 
Parking
 
$20


Chapter 90
 
All other violations of Chapter 90 except for §§  90.03 and 90.25
 
$25    (first offense)


$50   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$100   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)


90.03(B)
 
Animal At Large
 
$50   (first offense)


$75   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$100   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)

Civil Emergencies
 
$30   (first offense)


$60   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$90   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)


Chapter 95
 
Noise Control
 
$30   (first offense)


$60   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$90   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)

Nuisance (provided all cited violations have been abated and excepting
violations of the Property Maintenance Code)
 
$25   (first offense)


$50   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)

$100   (fourth of subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)

Trash
 
$25   (first offense)


$50   (second offense within 12 months of first offense)


$75   (third or subsequent offense within 12 months of first offense)




 



   (D)   Where a subsequent violation is charged, it must be
specifically stated on the written citation for the enhanced penalty to be
applied through the Violations Bureau.



   (E)   All payments to the Violations Clerk in satisfaction of the
penalties stated above must be by bank treasurer's check, cashier's check,
money order or certified check.



   (F)   If any person charged with a code violation does not admit the
civil violation(s), as charged, before the Violations Clerk and pay the
proscribed civil penalty within 30 days of receipt of the citation and prior
to the date noticed for hearing, then such person must appear before the
Frankfort City Court as noticed.



   (G)   The opportunity to appear before the Violations Clerk and to
admit the violation and to pay a civil penalty to the Violations Bureau,
shall only apply to citations pending before the Frankfort City Court and
shall, specifically, not be available where civil complaints for ordinance
violations are filed in Clinton Circuit Court or Clinton Superior Court.



   (H)   (1)   All civil penalty amounts collected through the
Violations Bureau, with the exception of penalties collected under Chapter
96, Chapter 98, and penalties collected under Chapter 90 for citations
written by employees of the Humane Society of Clinton County, Inc., shall be
deposited into the following city funds in the respective portions shown:



         (a)   One-fourth to city General Fund;



         (b)   One-fourth to the Clerk-Treasurer Administrative
Fund; and



         (c)   One-half to the Police Equipment and Training Fund.



      (2)   Civil penalties collected through the Violations Bureau
for Chapter 96 and Chapter 98 violations shall be deposited into the
following city funds in the respective portions shows:



         (a)   One-fourth to city General Fund;



         (b)   One-fourth to the Clerk-Treasurer Administrative
Fund; and



         (c)   One-half to the City Engineer's Equipment,
Training and Supply Fund.



      (3)   Civil penalties collected through the Violations Bureau
for citations written by employees of the Humane Society of Clinton County,
Inc. shall be deposited into the following city funds in the respective
portions shown:



         (a)   One-half to the Clerk-Treasurer Administrative
Fund; and



         (b)   One-half to a city fund hereby created and
identified as the Humane Society Enforcement Fund, which fund shall be
utilized and administered by the Board of Public Works and Safety, to
compensate Clinton County, Indiana, through its Board of Commissioners, for
Clinton County’s financial support of the Humane Society of Clinton County,
Inc.



(Ord. CO-88-18, passed 1-23-89; Am. Ord. CO-90-11, passed 12-10-90; Am. Ord.
CO-18-16C, passed 3-9-09; Am. Ord. 11-02A, passed 4-11-11; Am. Ord. 11-07,
passed 5-23-11; Am. Ord. 17-08, passed 8-14-17)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to establish Ordinance Violations Bureau, see I.C. 33-36-2-1
