I.C. 9-21-16-5



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 72.01  PARKING IN CONGESTED TRAFFIC AREA.



   The Common Council hereby determines that because of the flow of
traffic on streets or portions of streets within the congested traffic area,
as defined in § 73.10, parking therein shall be subject to the provisions of
this Title.  The congested area may be enlarged from time to time as traffic
conditions require by designation as congested traffic areas any other
streets or alleys as Common Council shall designate.



('75 Code, §  29.01)  (Ord. 152, passed 8-10-48; Am. Ord. 161, passed
3-3-52; Am. Ord. 162, passed 5-5- 52)



§ 72.02  PARKING WITHIN MARKED PARKING SPACES.



   (A)   Parking spaces shall be marked upon the streets of the city
only upon the order of the Board of Public Works and Safety.  ('75 Code, §
29.02)



   (B)   All motor vehicles or other vehicles parked upon or in streets
upon which parking spaces have been designated by lines, painted or otherwise
placed upon the streets of the city, shall be parked within a space so that
no part of the vehicle touches any of the lines designating the parking
space, and it shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be parked upon or in any
such street in any other manner.  However, nothing in this section shall
prohibit trucks from parking on any street where parking spaces are parallel
with the curb within the parallel spaces between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and
7:00 a.m.  ('75 Code, § 29.03)



(Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.03  PARKING ON STREETS WITH NO MARKED PARKING SPACES.



   All motor vehicles or other vehicles parked upon or in streets upon
which no parking spaces have been designated shall be parked parallel to the
curb, with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle not further than one foot
from the curb, and on the right side of the street.  It shall be unlawful
for any vehicle to be parked upon or in any such street in any other manner.



('75 Code, §  29.04)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.04  PARKING SPACES NOT RESERVED; EXCEPTIONS.



   No parking spaces shall be reserved for the use of a particular person,
firm, corporation, official, employee, or other legal entity, except that the
Board of Public Works and Safety shall have the power to reserve parking
space for the use of the Police Department for police vehicles bearing
designation thereon as such.  The Board shall also have the power to reserve
spaces for loading and unloading zones as provided in § 72.15.



('75 Code, §  29.05)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48; Am. Ord. 159, passed
3-3-52)



§ 72.05  PARKING IN ALLEYS, ON SIDEWALKS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle or other vehicle to
park in any alley.  However, this section shall not apply to motor vehicles
parking in alleys for a period of not more than 30 minutes for the purpose of
loading or unloading the vehicles.  ('75 Code, § 29.06)



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle or other
vehicle or any part of a vehicle on any sidewalk in the city.  ('75 Code, §
29.07)



   (C)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or
park any motor vehicle on any portion of a lot, lawn or greenspace in any
residential district other than on a drive of approved parking area.  No
person shall operate or park any vehicle over the curb or curb area unless
through a properly designed and designated curb cut.



      (2)   Exception:  parking on any portion of a lot, lawn or
greenspace in a residential district for the purpose of loading or unloading
or washing of the motor vehicle shall not exceed a reasonable amount of time
necessary to accomplish the task.



(Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48; Am. Ord. CO-05-07, passed 10-11-05)  Penalty,
see § 70.99



§ 72.06  BUSES, TRUCKS NEAR PUBLIC SQUARE.



   It shall be unlawful to park any truck or bus of more than 3/4-ton
capacity on any street adjacent to the public square. However, nothing in
this section shall be construed to prohibit trucks or buses from parking upon
these streets for the purpose of loading and unloading only.  ('75 Code,
§  29.08)  (Ord.  155, passed 10-28-48; Am. Ord. 85-22, passed 1-27-86) 
Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.07  PARKING WITHOUT LIGHTS.



   Any automobile parked on any highway in the city in accordance with the
parking regulations of the city, shall not require any lights on the vehicle
while it is so parked if the vehicle is parked at a place where there is
sufficient light so as to disclose and reveal the automobile at a distance of
500 feet.



('75 Code, §  29.09)  (Ord.  155, passed 10-28-48)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.08  PARKING ON ONE SIDE OF STREET.



   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle or other vehicle along
the side of any street which has been posted with signs prohibiting parking
on that side.



('75 Code, §  29.12)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.09  PARKING LONGER THAN TWO DAYS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle or other vehicle on any
street in the city for a period of more than 48 hours continuously.



('75 Code, §  29.14)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.10  PARKING ON NARROW STREETS.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city shall have the power
to restrict parking along one side of any street 28 feet or less in width
from curb to curb, and to cause to be posted thereon signs prohibiting
parking.  These signs shall be posted not less than one sign to each 100
feet if the street in the area thereby restricted.



('75 Code, §  29.19)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)



§ 72.11  COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS PROHIBITED.



   The driver of any commercial vehicle, including a truck or tractor with
a registered gross weight in excess of 7,000 pounds, or any semi-tractor
trailer, or trailer is prohibited from parking the vehicle upon a public
street in a residential district in the city, except in an emergency or
temporarily during those times as the vehicle is being loaded or unloaded.



('75 Code, §  27.03)  (Ord. PO-68-2, passed 8-7-68)  Penalty, see § 70.99



Cross-reference:



   Driving commercial vehicles prohibited on certain streets; exceptions,
see § 71.01



§ 72.12  VIOLATIONS.



   Any person, firm, or corporation who shall violate any of the
provisions of §§ 72.01 through 72.10, upon the determination of any police
officer of the City Police Department that the vehicle impedes the orderly
flow of traffic or constitutes a traffic hazard or a public nuisance, the
officer shall have the authority to tow away the vehicle.



§ 72.13  PARKING VEHICLES FACING ONCOMING TRAFFIC.



   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle or other vehicle along
the side of any street so that the vehicle faces oncoming traffic from the
nearest lane of travel.



(Ord. CO-86-11, passed 9-8-86)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.14  PARKING DURING SNOW EMERGENCIES.



   When the Mayor or his or her designee has proclaimed a snow emergency
the following parking regulation will be followed:



   (A)   On odd numbered days parking will be on the odd numbered side
of the street.  On even numbered days, parking will be on the even numbered
side of the street.  If one side of the street is normally marked “no
parking”, the no parking order shall not be enforced during a snow
emergency.  Any snow emergency declared shall run from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.



   (B)   If a car is parked on the wrong side of the street, the
penalty will be that the car is towed at the owner’s expense.



(Ord. CO-02-22, passed 1-27-03)



LOADING AND UNLOADING



§ 72.15  DESIGNATED ZONES; TIME LIMIT.



   (A)   No parking spaces shall be reserved for the use of a
particular person, firm, corporation, official, employee, or other legal
entity.  However, the Board of Public Works and Safety shall have the power
to reserve a parking space or spaces for the loading and unloading of
inter-city buses.  The Board shall also have the power from time to time,
whether in areas posted with parking meters or otherwise, to designate and
reserve loading and unloading space or spaces for trucks for the loading and
unloading of articles of intra-and inter-city commerce.



   (B)   Loading and unloading zones and the parking time limit therein
shall not exceed 30 minutes, to be designated from time to time by the Board
by erecting or causing to be erected proper and suitable signs and warnings
designating this, with regard to the proper flow and safety of traffic,
vehicular and pedestrian, with regard to a fair apportionment of the time for
loading and unloading trucks therein with regard to a convenient location
therefor from the standpoint of all such traffic, and with regard to an
equitable apportionment of loading and unloading distance among the trucks
involved.



('75 Code, §  27.05)  (Ord. 155, passed 10-28-48)



   (C)   There shall be no more than one truck loading and unloading
zone on any side of any street within any block of the city.  ('75 Code, §
27.06)



(Ord.  159, passed 3-3-52)



§ 72.16  UNAUTHORIZED PARKING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person
operating any vehicle other than one for which the reservation or designation
is made, as stated in § 72.15, to park the vehicle in or enter the vehicle
into any space or spaces, reserved or designated as provided in § 72.15(A).



('75 Code, §  27.07)  (Ord. 159, passed 3-3-52)  Penalty, see § 70.99



PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY



§ 72.20  UNAUTHORIZED PARKING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle, house
trailer, one-, two-, or three- wheeled trailer, tractor-trailer, or any other
type of motorized or nonmotorized conveyance ordinarily pulled or attached to
a motor vehicle, on any private property, private road, driveway, or parking
lot, without the express or implied consent or authorization of the owner,
holder, occupant, or lessee of the property.  Complaints for the violation
of this section shall be made by the owner, holder, occupant, or lessee of
the property to the Police Department.



('75 Code, §  27.14)  (Ord. PO-68-4, passed 11-13-68)  Penalty, see §
70.99



§ 72.21  REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED VEHICLE.



   (A)   When a complaint is made to the Police Department regarding
unauthorized parking, the investigating officer shall complete an appropriate
complaint form and have it signed by the complainant.  The vehicle shall be
ticketed for a violation of this section of the code and any other applicable
sections.



   (B)   If, in the opinion of the investigating officer, the illegally
parked vehicle is causing an emergency situation by preventing proper ingress
or egress of any foot or vehicular traffic, or by preventing free movement of
traffic, he may direct the vehicle to be removed by a reputable towing firm
to a reputable storage or parking garage.  The investigating officer may
also direct the removal of the vehicle if the vehicle remains illegally
parked on any private property, private road or driveway, or parking lot
after the vehicle is ticketed for unauthorized parking, or if the record
shows that the particular vehicle has had many repeated offenses for
unauthorized parking so as to be considered a habitual nuisance.



('75 Code, §  27.15)  (Ord. PO-68-4, passed 11-13-68)



§ 72.22  TOWING AND STORAGE CHARGES.



   Before the owner or person in charge of any impounded vehicle shall be
permitted to remove it from the custody of the owner, agent, employer, or
lessee of the parking area or garage where the vehicle has been stored, he
will pay any and all towing charges plus storage charges.  He will also read
and adhere to the instructions on the violation ticket placed on the vehicle
by the investigating officer.



('75 Code, §  27.16)  (Ord. PO-68-4, passed 11-13-68)



§ 72.23  PRESUMPTION THAT OWNER PARKED VEHICLE.



   In any proceeding for the violation of §§ 72.20 through 72.22, the
registration plate displayed on the motor vehicle shall constitute in
evidence a prima-facie presumption that the owner of the motor vehicle was
the person who parked or placed the motor vehicle at the place where the
violation occurred.



('75 Code, §  27.17)  (Ord.  PO-68-4, passed 11-13-68)



CHAPTER 73:  DOWNTOWN PARKING



Section



General Provisions



   73.01   On-street parking regulations; purpose



   73.02   Parking prohibited



   73.03   Designation of two-hour on-street parking



   73.04   Time limit for parking in spaces reserved for disabled
persons



   73.05   Parking time limit modification



Off-Street Parking



   73.10   Designation of off-street parking lots



   73.11   Operation of off-street parking lots



   73.12   Off-street parking signs



   73.13   Off-street parking violations



Violations; Enforcement



   73.20   Parking violation; civil infraction; fine



   73.21   Repeat violations within one calendar year



   73.22   Notice on illegally parked vehicle



   73.23   Presumption in reference to illegal parking



   73.24   Enforcement



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 73.01  ON-STREET PARKING REGULATIONS; PURPOSE.



   In addition to other parking, stopping and standing provisions of
Chapter 72 and other provisions of the Municipal Code of the City of
Frankfort, this chapter is enacted to regulate the parking of motor vehicles
in the downtown area of the city. The purpose of this chapter is to designate
specific areas of public streets and lots in the city where the parking of
motor vehicles is limited, prohibited, or regulated as to the time permitted
for such parking, and to impose penalties for the violation of such
regulations. The limitations, prohibitions and motor vehicle parking time
limits provided by this chapter are intended to reduce traffic obstructions,
to provide for the orderly flow of traffic and to encourage economic
development and business success in the downtown area of the city by
providing for limited free on-street parking for customers of stores and
other businesses in the downtown area of the city in order to achieve a rapid
movement of motor vehicles into and out of the downtown area.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.02  PARKING PROHIBITED.



   No person shall park a motor vehicle upon any of the streets or
portions of streets adjacent or next to curbs which are painted yellow, or
adjacent or next to curbs or the edges of pavement in areas designated by
signage as “no parking.”  No person shall park a motor vehicle on or
along the sides of streets on which parking has been prohibited under Chapter
77 of the Municipal Code of the City of Frankfort.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.03  DESIGNATION OF TWO-HOUR ON-STREET PARKING.



   (A)   Where not otherwise prohibited, motor vehicles may be parked
on the public streets of the City of Frankfort without charge; provided,
however, that between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on all days except
Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, no person shall park a motor vehicle
for more than two hours in any of the parking spaces located on a public
street in the area of the city bounded by the following description:



      Beginning at the intersection of the south boundary of the
Norfolk and Western Railroad and the west side of North Columbia Street and
running south along the west side of Columbia Street to the north side of
Clinton Street; thence west along the north side of Clinton Street to the
vacated alley lying along the west side of Lot 105 of the Original Plat to
the City of Frankfort; thence south to the alley lying along the west side of
Lot 104 of the said Original Plat to the northwest corner of said Lot 104;
thence east along the south side of Clinton Street to the west side of
Columbia Street; thence south along the west side of Columbia Street to the
north right of way line of State Road 28; thence east along the north
right-of-way line of State Road 28 to a point on the west side of Jackson
Street being the west right-of-way line of State Road 39; thence north along
the west right-of-way line of State Road 39 to a point on the south line of
East Clinton Street; thence east along the south line of East Clinton Street
to a point on the east side of Sycamore Street extended; thence north along
the east side of Sycamore Street to a point on the north side of Washington
Street; thence west along the north side of Washington Street to a point on
the east side of Jackson Street being the east right-of-way line of State
Road 39; thence north along the east line of Jackson Street to the south
boundary of the Norfolk and Western Railroad; thence west along the said
south boundary of the Norfolk and Western Railroad to the point of beginning;
EXCEPTING THEREFROM  those parking spaces lying along the south side of East
Clinton Street between Jackson Street and Sycamore Street extended.



   (B)   For purposes of this chapter,LEGAL HOLIDAYS shall mean such
holidays as are determined by either the City of Frankfort or Clinton County
as non-working holidays for their employees.



   (C)   Motor vehicles parked on public streets and subject to the
two-hour time limit proscribed above may remain parked for longer periods if
an overtime parking permit is displayed as provided in § 73.05.



   (D)   Notwithstanding the provisions set forth above in this
section, the parking provisions and time limits described below shall be
applicable to the following specified parking spaces within that area:



      (1)   Two diagonal parking spaces shall be located on the west
side of the courthouse square and shall be designated by signage as being
reserved for the Clinton County Sheriff’s Department. The two spaces shall
be reserved for the use of such Sheriff’s officials during hours that the
courthouse is open to the public.



      (2)   One diagonal parking space shall be located on the west
side of North Main Street in front of Frankfort Municipal Utilities at 16
North Main, and shall be designated by signage as being reserved for
utilities customers for a 24-hour period.



      (3)   The diagonal parking spaces that are located along the
west side of North Columbia Street between West Washington Street and the
first east-west alley south of  Washington Street are reserved at all times
for the exclusive use of the Frankfort Police Department.



      (4)   The elected judges of the Circuit and Superior Courts of
Clinton County and the elected Prosecutor of Clinton County shall each be
allowed one parking permit to be displayed on their respective vehicles
authorizing permitted parking in the downtown area during such times that
they are performing official duties.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.04  TIME LIMIT FOR PARKING IN SPACES RESERVED FOR DISABLED PERSONS.



   It is a parking infraction for motor vehicles that are lawfully parked
in parking spaces designated for handicapped persons to be parked in such
spaces for more than two successive hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and
4:00 p.m. except Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays.  Handicapped parking
spaces shall be determined by the Board of Public Works and Safety and shall
be marked appropriately.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.05  PARKING TIME LIMIT MODIFICATION.



   (A)   By reason of the changing character of business activities
conducted in the downtown area described in § 73.03, above, and the desire
of merchants to extend or restrict the time permitted for motor vehicle
parking in front of or nearby their business locations, the Board of Public
Works and Safety, upon request of civic or governmental organizations, or
upon request of all business owners whose principal business entrance is
within those designated on-street parking spaces of the parking space or
spaces sought for time extension or restriction, may restrict or prohibit
parking or may extend the time limits allowed for motor vehicles parking at
any designated on-street parking space on streets within the downtown area.



   (B)   Motor vehicles that are parked by a person serving on jury
duty or a person who is a prospective juror in the Circuit or Superior Courts
of Clinton County shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter during
the time that such persons are serving on the jury or jury selection.  A
written notice of such jury duty shall be prominently displayed on the front
windshield or on the dashboard of the motor vehicle whose operator is serving
on jury duty. Such notice shall display the name of the court issuing the
notice and the date of issuance.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



OFF-STREET PARKING



§ 73.10  DESIGNATION OF OFF-STREET PARKING LOTS.



   (A)   The city shall operate and maintain off-street parking for
public use at paved lots located as follows:  Lots 19 and 20 in the Original
Plat of the City of Frankfort; Lot 140 in the Original Plat of the City of
Frankfort; and a city-owned area described as follows:  Beginning at the
intersection of the south right-of-way line of the Norfolk and Western
Railroad with the east line of North Jackson Street; thence south along the
east line of North Jackson Street to the north line of the property located
at 253 N. Jackson Street; thence east along said north property line of 253
N. Jackson Street to the west bank of Prairie Creek; thence north along said
west bank to the south right-of-way line of the Norfolk and Western Railroad;
thence west along said south right-of-way line to the point of beginning.



   (B)   The city shall also maintain off-street parking for public use
at the paved parking area comprising parts of Lots 30 and 31 in the Original
Plat of the City of Frankfort, except for nine parking spaces in that parking
area which shall be reserved for the Frankfort Utility Service Board and its
employees without charge.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.11  OPERATION OF OFF-STREET PARKING LOTS.



   (A)   The off-street parking facilities herein created and
established shall be operated by the city and the management and operation
thereof shall be conducted under the direction of the Board of Public Works
and Safety.



   (B)   The method of operation of the off-street parking facilities
herein created and established shall be as follows:



      (1)    Certain designated and marked spaces within the
off-street parking facilities herein created shall be rented on a monthly
basis taking into consideration the availability of other nearby parking
facilities and the demand for permanent parking. The monthly rental amount
shall be determined by resolution of the Board of Public Works and Safety. To
facilitate this provision, the Board of Public Works and Safety is authorized
to provide for the issuance and execution of rental agreements with renters
of parking spaces;



      (2)    Spaces within the off-street parking facilities
described in above in this section which are not rented may be used for
public parking without fee for a period not to exceed two hours.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.12  OFF-STREET PARKING SIGNS.



   Signs shall be posted at all off-street parking facilities reflecting
their availability to the public, the restrictions on their use, and
designating those spaces that have been rented as reserved.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.13  OFF-STREET PARKING VIOLATIONS.



   Except for Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, it is a parking
infraction for anyone other than the lessee of a reserved space to park a
motor vehicle in a city-designated off-street parking space that has been
designated as reserved. Further, on all days between the hours of 8:00 a.m.
and 4:00 p.m., except for Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, it shall be
an infraction to park a motor vehicle for a period in excess of two hours in
any designated off-street parking space that has not been reserved.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



VIOLATIONS; ENFORCEMENT



§ 73.20  PARKING VIOLATION; CIVIL INFRACTION; FINE.



   (A)   The parking of a motor vehicle in an on-street parking space
or in an off-street parking space in excess of the time limits set forth in
this chapter or in an area designated no parking, or in an area reserved for
another person, is a parking infraction and a violation of this chapter.



   (B)   The fine for parking a motor vehicle in violation of any
provision of this chapter is $20 for the first offense within a calendar year
and shall be paid to the Ordinance Violations Bureau of the City of Frankfort
within 30 days of issuance of the notice of violation. If the parking fine is
not paid within such 30-day period, collection of the fine, together with
court costs, will be pursued through the civil court process.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.21  REPEAT VIOLATIONS WITHIN ONE CALENDAR YEAR.



   (A)   For persons who commit repeated parking violations of this
chapter within one calendar year, the fine to be paid to the Ordinance
Violations Bureau shall be enhanced.  Upon a second such violation within
the same calendar year, the fine shall be $40. Upon a third or subsequent
such violation within the same calendar year, the fine shall be $100.



   (B)   Each subsequent violation of the posted period of parking time
constitutes another violation.  Calculation of the new period of parking
time begins immediately after a notice of infraction has been issued.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.22  NOTICE ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE.



   Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked, angle
parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this
chapter, the police officer or parking control officer finding such vehicle
shall complete a notice of traffic infraction and affix the same to such
vehicle in a conspicuous place.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.23  PRESUMPTION IN REFERENCE TO ILLEGAL PARKING.



   (A)   Any violation of a parking restriction as provided for in this
chapter shall be a violation by the registered owner of such vehicle and by
the driver who parked the vehicle at the location cited, if the driver is
other than the vehicle’s registered owner.



   (B)   In any prosecution charging a violation of any provisions
under this chapter governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that
the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of
any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in
the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of the
vehicle, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the registered owner of
such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point
where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



§ 73.24  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)    The provisions contained in this chapter apply to all
vehicles, whether they are self-propelled, animal drawn or towed, except for:



      (1)   Emergency vehicles when responding to an emergency call
or in pursuit of an alleged law violator;



      (2)   Highway construction vehicles when engaged in
construction work; and



      (3)   Other vehicles that are exempt from municipal parking
ordinances under applicable law.



   (B)   Any police officer of the City of Frankfort or parking control
officer designated as such by the Board of Public Works and Safety of the
City of Frankfort, who observes the violation of any provision of this
chapter shall attach to the offending vehicle a notice to the owner/operator
thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of same and advising
that such person may, within 30 days from the date of such notice, pay to the
Ordinance Violations Bureau of the City of Frankfort, as a fine for and in
full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of $20; that if the violation is
a second or third such offense within the same calendar year, the fine will
be $40 for the second such offense and $100 for the third or subsequent such
offense within the same calendar year; that, upon the failure of the
owner/operator to make such payment within the 30-day period, collection of
the fine, together with court costs, will be pursued through the civil court
process.



   (C)   Whenever a member of the Police Department or other person
charged with the enforcement of this chapter finds that any section or
sections are being violated or have been violated by the owner or operator of
any vehicle, he or she shall notify the owner or operator of such vehicle, in
writing, on a form to be provided by the city, of such violation.



      (1)   The notice shall:



         (a)   Be made in duplicate;



         (b)   Be serially numbered;



         (c)   Show the specific violation charged;



         (d)   Show the registration or state license number of
the vehicle involved;



         (e)   Show the violator’s name, address, and
operator’s license number, if possible to obtain the same; and



         (f)   State any other information which the officer may
then and there discover.



      (2)   One copy of the notice shall be presented to the
violator, owner or operator of such vehicle.  In case such violator,
operator or owner shall not be in possession of the vehicle, the posting of
such notice or the attachment thereof to a conspicuous place on such vehicle
shall be deemed a sufficient notice of such violation. The notice shall
specify the amount of the fine and shall state that the fine shall be paid to
the Ordinance Violations Bureau. The notice shall also provide the address of
the Ordinance Violations Bureau where the fine may be paid in person or by
mail; that if the fine is not timely paid, the fine will be collected,
together with court costs, through the civil court process. The officer
serving such notice shall file the duplicate copy in the office of the
Ordinance Violations Bureau.



   (D)   If a motor vehicle is determined to have been parked
continuously for a period of 48 hours in violation of any provision of this
chapter, the city may authorize such vehicle to be towed to an automobile
salvage yard or to a city owned or leased area with the cost of such tow to
be paid by the vehicle owner in addition to any fines.



   (E)   If it appears from the City Court records that three judgments
concerning a motor vehicle have not been paid before deadlines established by
this chapter, the Clerk of the Court, pursuant to I.C. 9-30-11-3, shall send
a notice to the person who is the registered owner of the motor vehicle
informing such person as follows:



      (1)   That the clerk will send a referral of non-payment to
the Indiana Bureau of Motor Vehicles if the judgments are not paid within 30
days after a notice was mailed.



      (2)   That the referral will result in the suspension of the
motor vehicle’s registration if the judgments are not paid.



   (F)    All fines received by the City Court for violations of this
chapter shall be deposited into the city’s General Fund pursuant to
applicable law.



(Ord. CO-13-17, passed 3-10-14)



CHAPTER 74:  NON-MOTORIZED VEHICLES



Section



General Provisions



   74.01   Definition



License Regulations



   74.05   License required



   74.06   Application; fee



   74.07   Issuance



   74.08   Attachment of license plates



   74.09   Inspection of bicycle



   74.10   Renewal or replacement of license



   74.11   Transfer of ownership of bicycle



Traffic Rules



   74.15   Scope and application



   74.16   Obedience to traffic-control devices



   74.17   Correct method of riding



   74.18   Speed



   74.19   Right-hand side of roadway



   74.20   Emerging from alley or driveway



   74.21   Clinging to vehicles



   74.22   Riding in group



   74.23   Carrying articles



   74.24   Parking



   74.25   Bicycle paths; sidewalks



Equipment



   74.30   Lamps, lights, and reflectors



   74.31   Brakes



 



   74.99   Penalty



Statutory reference:



   Authority to regulate bicycles, see I.C. 9-21-11



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 74.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter the term FOOT-PROPELLED VEHICLE shall
include any bicycle, skateboard, scooter or roller skates.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



LICENSE REGULATIONS



§ 74.05  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person who rides within this City shall ride or propel a bicycle on
any street, on any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles,
or on any sidewalk, unless the bicycle has been licensed and a license plate
attached thereto as provided in this subchapter.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.06  APPLICATION; FEE.



   Application for a bicycle license shall be made upon a form provided by
the city, and shall be made to the Police Department.  A license fee of $2
shall be paid to the city before each license or replacement thereof is
granted by the city.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91; Am. Ord. 08-09, passed 11-10-08)



§ 74.07  ISSUANCE.



   (A)   The Juvenile Aid Division, upon receiving proper application,
is hereby authorized to issue a bicycle license which shall be effective
until the license is mutilated, the bicycle is destroyed, or ownership of the
bicycle is transferred.  The Juvenile Aid Division shall not issue a license
for any bicycle when he knows, or has reasonable ground to believe, that the
applicant is not the owner or entitled to the possession of the bicycle.



   (B)   The Juvenile Aid Division shall cause a record to be kept of
the number of each license, the date the license is issued, the name and
address of the person to who it is issued, and the number of the frame of the
bicycle for which the license is issued.  He shall also keep a record of all
bicycle license fees collected by him.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



§ 74.08  ATTACHMENT OF LICENSE PLATES.



   The Juvenile Aid Division upon issuing a bicycle license shall also
issue a license plate bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and
the name of the city thereon.  The Juvenile Aid Divison shall cause the
license plate to be firmly attached to the bicycle for which it has been
issued, upon that part of the frame extending from the seat to the sprocket
housing.  No person shall remove a license plate from a bicycle during the
period for which issued except upon the transfer of ownership, or in the
event the bicycle is dismantled or is no longer operative.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



§ 74.09  INSPECTION OF BICYCLE.



   The Juvenile Aid Division may cause each bicycle to be inspected before
issuing a license for it, and shall refuse to issue a license for any bicycle
which, after an inspection, is determined to be in an unsafe mechanical
condition and not properly equipped in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



§ 74.10  RENEWAL OR REPLACEMENT OF LICENSE.



   Upon the mutilation, destruction, or loss of any bicycle license, the
same may be replaced upon proper application for replacement or renewal and
the payment of the same fee that was paid when the license was originally
issued.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



§ 74.11  TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP OF BICYCLE.



   Upon the sale or transfer of ownership of any licensed bicycle, the
license shall become void and the new owner shall apply for a new license as
provided in § 74.08.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



TRAFFIC RULES



§ 74.15  SCOPE AND APPLICATION.



   (A)   No person shall do any act forbidden, or fail to perform any
act required in this chapter.  The parent of any child and the guardian of
any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit his child or ward to violate
any of the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   These regulations applicable to foot-propelled vehicles shall
apply whenever a foot-propelled vehicle is operated on any street or any
public path set aside for the exclusive use of any f00t-propelled vehicle
subject to any exceptions stated herein.



   (C)   Every person riding a foot-propelled vehicle upon any public
highway or street in the city shall be subject to the provisions of the
traffic rules and ordinances of this city applicable to the driver of a
motorized vehicle. However, special regulations in this chapter, and those
provisions of the traffic rules and ordinances which by their nature can have
no application shall not apply to foot-propelled vehicles.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.16  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   (A)   Any person operating a foot-propelled vehicle shall obey the
instructions of official traffic signals, signs, and other control devices
applicable to motorized vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a traffic
officer.



   (B)   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no
right, left or "U" turns are permitted, no person operating a foot-propelled
vehicle shall disobey the direction of the sign. However, where the person
dismounts from the foot-propelled vehicle to make the turn, he shall then
obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.17  CORRECT METHOD OF RIDING.



   (A)   A person riding a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or
astride the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor carry any other
person upon the bicycle other than upon a firmly attached and regular seat
thereon.  No person shall ride a bicycle other than as authorized herein.



   (B)   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time
than the number for which it is designed and equipped.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.18  SPEED.



   No person shall operate a foot-propelled vehicle at a speed greater
than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.19  RIGHT-HAND SIDE OF ROADWAY.



   Every person operating a foot-propelled vehicle upon the highway or
street shall ride as near to the right-hand side of the highway or street as
practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one
proceeding in the same direction.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.20  EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY.



   The operator of a foot-propelled vehicle emerging from an alley,
driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or sidewalk area
extending across any alley or driveway, yield the right-of-way to all
pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering
the highway or street shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles
approaching on the roadway.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.21  CLINGING TO VEHICLES.



   No person riding a foot-propelled vehicle shall attach themselves or
their vehicle onto any motorized vehicle.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.22  RIDING IN GROUP.



   Persons operating foot-propelled vehicles upon a highway or street
shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of highways or
streets set aside for the exclusive use of foot-propelled vehicles.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.23  CARRYING ARTICLES.



   No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or
article which prevents the operator of the bicycle from keeping both hands on
the handlebars of the bicycle simultaneously.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.24  PARKING.



   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the
roadway against the curb, upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle,
against the building, or at the curb.  All foot-propelled vehicles shall be
parked in a manner affording the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.25  BICYCLE PATHS; SIDEWALKS.



   No person shall ride or operate a foot-propelled vehicle between the
hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. upon any sidewalk within the city in the
area bounded by Walnut Street on the south, Morrison Street on the north,
Clay Street on the east, and Columbia Street, between Morrison and Washington
Street and Taylor Street between Washington and Walnut Street, on the west,
nor in front of any public building, nor upon any public parking lot or
pedestrian concourse within this designated area.  Any type of
foot-propelled vehicle may be restricted or prohibited upon any privately
owned sidewalk or property upon conspicuous- posting of said restrictions or
prohibitions by the owners or agents of said property.  Otherwise, when any
person is riding or operating a foot-propelled vehicle upon a sidewalk, such
person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an
audible signal a reasonable time before overtaking or passing such pedestrian.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



EQUIPMENT



§ 74.30  LAMPS, LIGHTS, AND REFLECTORS.



   Every bicycle, when in use between dusk and dawn, shall be equipped
with either a lamp or light on the front end which emits a white light
visible for a distance of at least 500 feet, and with a red reflector on the
rear of the bicycle which shall be visible for a distance of at least 500
feet.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.31  BRAKES.



   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the
operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)  Penalty, see § 74.99



§ 74.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be
subject to a civil penalty of $15; $30 for any second violation committed
within 30 days of any prior violation of this chapter and $50 for any third
or subsequent violation committed within one year of any prior violations of
this chapter. At the option of the ordinance violator, the fine for the first
violation may be waived upon the offender's completion of four hours of
community service, the fine for any second violation committed within 30 days
of any prior violation of this chapter may be waived, at the option of the
violator, upon completion of eight hours of community service.



   (B)   In addition, any police officer who observes a person
violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall confiscate the
foot-propelled vehicle of the person in violation of the provisions of this
chapter and retain the same for any period not less than one day nor more
than 14 days.  If the confiscated foot-propelled vehicle was being used by
an individual under 18 years of age, the minor must be accompanied by his
parent or guardian to retrieve the foot-propelled vehicle.



(Ord. CO-91-3, passed 5-13-91)



CHAPTER 75:  RAILROADS



Section



General Provisions



   75.01   Speed limits



   75.02   Hopping trains while in motion



   75.03   Interference with railroad equipment



Railroad Crossings



   75.10   Automatic signals



   75.11   Installation, maintenance of signal crossings



 



   75.99   Penalty



   Appendix A:  Crossing requiring signal or flagman



   Appendix B:  Exempt crossings



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 75.01  SPEED LIMITS.



   Any railroad locomotives and railroad trains operating in or through
the city shall not be operated at a speed greater than 35 miles per hour.



('75 Code, §  45.05)  (Ord. 158, passed 2-18-52)  Penalty, see § 75.99



§ 75.02  HOPPING TRAINS WHILE IN MOTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of railroad
companies, to get on or off, or attempt to get on or off, any locomotive car
or cars while it is in motion, at any point within the corporate limits of
the city.



('75 Code, §  45.10)  (Ord. ll, passed 2-16-1876)  Penalty, see § 75.99



§ 75.03  INTERFERENCE WITH RAILROAD EQUIPMENT.



   Any person who is not a railroad employee, who shall unlock or break
any lock, padlock, or any other fastening whereby any car, hand car, or
switch is fastened; change or turn any switch; or in any manner place
obstructions on any railroad track within the corporate limits of the city,
shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section.



('75 Code, §  45.11)  (Ord. ll, passed 2-16-1876)  Penalty, see § 75.99



RAILROAD CROSSINGS



§ 75.10  AUTOMATIC SIGNALS.



   (A)   Whenever any railroad running into or through the city is
ordered by a city ordinance to maintain any flashing light signals or a
crossing watchman at any street crossing in the city, the railroad may
install an automatic signal at the crossing.



   (B)   Any automatic signal erected by any railroad need not give
warning of the approach of any motor car on the railroad, provided that the
person or persons operating the motor car shall keep the car under control at
all times, and grant the right-of-way to any vehicular or pedestrian traffic
crossing the railroad at all street crossings in the city.



('75 Code, §  45.01)  (Ord. 163, passed 8-18-52)  Penalty, see § 75.99



§ 75.11  INSTALLATION, MAINTENANCE OF SIGNAL CROSSINGS.



   It shall be the duty of the railroad companies named in Appendix A at
the end of this chapter, and their successors and assigns, to install and
maintain at the railroad crossings listed in Appendix A, standard electric
signaling devices for the warning and protection of persons crossing the
railroads at those points.  All of the signals referred to herein shall be
maintained and operated at all times so that protection is given at each of
the crossings for 24 hours a day. In the event any of the signals are out of
operation, the railroad company is hereby required to protect all of the
crossings by a watchman or otherwise during the time the signals are not in
operation.



('75 Code, §  45.03)  (Ord. 79, passed 6-4-26)  Penalty, see § 75.99



§ 75.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which
another penalty is not provided, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding
$300.  Every day any violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.  ('75 Code, § l.08)



   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation operating or causing to be
operated a railroad locomotive or railroad train at a speed greater than 35
miles per hour in or through the city shall be guilty of a violation of §
75.01, and may be fined in any sum not exceeding $100.



('75 Code, §  45.06)  (Ord. 158, passed 2-18-52)



   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating the provisions of
§ 75.02 (A) shall be fined any sum not exceeding $100.



('75 Code, §  45.09)  (Ord. 146, passed 10-14-43)



   (D)   Any person found guilty and convicted of a violation of § 
75.04 shall be fined in any sum not less than $10 nor more than $500.  ('75
Code, §  45.12)  (Ord. 11, passed 2-16-1876; Am. Ord. PO-77-2, passed
12-21-77)



   (E)   Any person or persons violating the terms and provisions of
§§ 75.10 and 75.11 shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100. ('75
Code, §  45.04)  (Ord. 163, passed 8-18-52)

Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company

are hereby prohibited from operating or driving the vehicles over any city
streets or portions of streets, except those through commercial routes as
specified below.

SCHEDULE III:  PREFERENTIAL STREETS.



   The following streets shall hereafter be preferential streets. It shall
be unlawful to cross these streets or to enter upon them from any
intersecting street, alley, or private driveway with any motor vehicle
without the vehicle being brought to a stop within 15 feet of a line made by
a continuation of the curb lines of the preferential streets across
intersecting streets, alleys, or private driveways. Any person, firm, or
corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this schedule, upon
the determination of any police officer of the City Police Department that
the vehicle impedes the orderly flow of traffic or constitutes a traffic
hazard or a public nuisance, the officer shall have the authority to tow away
the vehicle.

CHAPTER 78:  MOPEDS



Section



General Provisions



   78.01   Definition



   78.02   Operation with consent of owner



License Regulations



   78.15   License required



   78.16   Application for registration and license



   78.17   Mechanical examination; fee; issuance of license; attachment
of plate or sticker



   78.18   Duration of license



   78.19   Record of license



   78.20   Transfer of ownership



Administration and Enforcement



   78.35   Loss or destruction of plate or sticker



   78.36   Inspections



   78.37   Chief of Police to administer enforcement; suspension or
revocation of license; impoundment



 



   78.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 78.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MOPED.  A vehicle with two tandem wheels, or three wheels, with solid
or pneumatic tires, having a steering bar or wheel, a seat, and pedals so
that the vehicle is capable of being propelled by motor or human power, or by
both, and when powered by an engine having a rating of no more than l.5 brake
horse power and a cylinder capacity not exceeding 50 cubic centimeters, an
automatic transmission, and a maximum design speed of no more than 25 miles
per hour on a flat surface.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.02  OPERATION WITH CONSENT OF OWNER.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any moped within
the city without the consent of the owner.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86) Penalty, see § 78.99



LICENSE REGULATIONS



§ 78.15  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a moped upon any street,
sidewalk, or any other public place in the city, without having first
registered the moped and secured a license.  The license shall authorize the
operation of the motorized bicycle upon the streets, alleys, and public
highways of the city provided that no such vehicle shall carry anyone other
than the operator.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86) Penalty, see § 78.99



§ 78.16  APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION AND LICENSE.



   (A)   Application for registration and license for a moped shall be
made by the owner in writing, in duplicate, upon blank forms furnished by the
Police Department.



   (B)   The application shall be signed by the owner and if the owner
is a person under 18 years of age, the signature shall be witnessed by a
parent of the owner; or if no parent is living, then by the legal guardian of
the owner.  The application shall state the full name and address of the
owner of the moped, the name of the manufacturer, the serial number of the
frame thereof, the approximate date when the owner obtained the title
thereto, and if not new when obtained, the name and address of the person
from whom it was obtained.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.17  MECHANICAL EXAMINATION; FEE; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; ATTACHMENT OF
PLATE OR STICKER.



   The Chief of Police or some person authorized by him or her shall
examine the moped and if he or she finds the mechanical condition thereof
such that it can be safely operated and finds that the statements made in the
application are true, and after a license fee of $10 has been paid by the
applicant, he or she shall issue a license plate or sticker which shall
contain the words "Frankfort, Indiana," the number of the license, and the
year of issuance.  The registration card and license plate or sticker shall
have the same number.  The license plate or sticker shall be attached to the
moped on the rear fender.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86; Am. Ord. 08-10, passed 11-10-08)



§ 78.18  DURATION OF LICENSE.



   The license so issued shall be effective for one year.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.19  RECORD OF LICENSE.



   After the issuance of the registration card and plate or sticker, the
Police Department shall endorse upon the application and the duplicate the
date of issuance and the number thereof.  The original application and the
duplicate shall be kept on file in the office of the Police Department.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.20  TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.



   (A)   When any moped has been registered and licensed as herein
provided, and is sold or is otherwise disposed of or destroyed, the licensee
shall immediately surrender to the Chief of Police the registration card and
the license plate or sticker issued therefor, with the name and address of
the new owner, if any, written on the face of the registration card.  The
Chief of Police shall immediately make proper endorsements thereon on his
records and deliver the card and plate or sticker to the City Clerk-Treasurer
who shall immediately make proper endorsements on his or her records, retain
the card and plate or sticker and issue a new card and plate or sticker to
the new owner for a charge of $5.



   (B)   The number of any license surrendered as provided in this
section shall not be reissued.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT



§ 78.35  LOSS OR DESTRUCTION OF PLATE OR STICKER.



   (A)   The licensee shall report immediately to Chief of Police the
loss or destruction of the license plate or sticker of the licensee and the
circumstances surrounding the loss or destruction thereof. With the approval
of the Chief of Police a duplicate license plate or sticker will be issued
upon payment of a fee of $5.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person willfully or maliciously
to remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter the serial number of any moped
licensed hereunder; or to remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter any
registration is in force.  The Chief of Police is authorized to stamp
numbers on the frame of the moped in a legible manner for identification
purposes upon which no serial number can be found or upon which the serial
number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the city or
any dealer in mopeds operating in the city to purchase, receive in trade, or
otherwise acquire any moped from which the serial number on the frame has
been removed, destroyed, mutilated, or altered without first reporting the
same to the Chief of Police.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.36  INSPECTIONS.



   Any member of the Police Department is authorized to inspect any moped
at any reasonable time for the purpose of making a check of the license plate
or sticker and license serial number and for the purpose of determining the
mechanical condition of the moped.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.37  CHIEF OF POLICE TO ADMINISTER ENFORCEMENT; SUSPENSION OR
REVOCATION OF LICENSE; IMPOUNDMENT.



   (A)   The Chief of Police shall enforce the provisions of this
chapter.



   (B)   The Chief may revoke or suspend for a period of 30 days, any
moped license for any violation of any provision of this chapter or any
applicable provision of the statutes relating to traffic. In addition, the
Chief may impound the moped of any such violator for a period not exceeding
30 days.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



§ 78.99  PENALTY.



   Violations of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than $10 and no more than $500.  Whenever possible under the provisions of
the laws of the state, operator's or chauffeur's licenses of persons
convicted of a third violation of this chapter shall be suspended or revoked
for whatever period of time, within the discretion of the trial judge, is
deemed advisable.



(Ord. CO-86-12, passed 8-11-86)



CHAPTER 79:  GOLF CARTS



Section



   79.01   Definition; scope



   79.02   Minimum age to operate



   79.03   Daytime operation



   79.04   Registration



   79.05   Prohibited operation



   79.06   Rules of operation



   79.07   Seating



   79.08   Equipment



   79.09   Operation during special events



   79.10   Exemptions



 



   79.99   Penalty



§ 79.01  DEFINITION; SCOPE.



   (A)   Definition. For the purposes of this chapter, the following
definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      GOLF CART. Has the meaning as defined in I.C. 9-13-2-69.7, as
amended, which defines a golf cart to mean “a four-wheeled motor vehicle
originally and specifically designed and intended to transport one or more
individuals and golf clubs for the purpose of playing the game of golf on a
golf course.”



   (B)   Scope. The requirements and restrictions imposed by this
chapter as to the operation of golf carts shall refer only to the operation
of golf carts on streets and alleys within the jurisdiction of the city.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)



§ 79.02  MINIMUM AGE TO OPERATE.



   Only a licensed driver, age 18 or older, shall be allowed to operate a
golf cart in the city on public streets or alleys within the city.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.03  DAYTIME OPERATION.



   Golf carts shall only be operated on public streets and alleys within
the city during the period of time from sunrise to sunset year around.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.04  REGISTRATION.



   (A)   Any golf cart operating on a public street or alley within the
city must be registered with the city through the Frankfort Police Department
prior to use within the city. The license registration shall be effective for
one year.



   (B)   At the time of registration, the owner shall present the golf
cart to the Frankfort Police Department for inspection.



   (C)   If the golf cart passes inspection, the owner shall pay a
registration fee to the Police Department of $50 annually and shall provide
proof of liability insurance/financial responsibility in an amount not less
than the minimum required by Indiana law for motor vehicles, at which time a
registration sticker will be issued. Proof of insurance and the registration
shall be maintained in the golf cart at all times and the registration
sticker shall be displayed on the rear driver side of the golf cart at all
times.



   (D)   All registration fees collected pursuant to this chapter shall
be deposited into the Police Equipment Fund maintained by the city.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12; Am. Ord. 14-01, passed 2-24-14)  Penalty, see
§ 79.99



§ 79.05  PROHIBITED OPERATION.



   (A)   No person shall operate a golf cart on Highway 28, on Highway
39/US Highway 421 or on Highway 75/38, except to cross such highways in a
perpendicular manner.



   (B)   Golf carts shall not be operated on sidewalks.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.06  RULES OF OPERATION.



   (A)   Persons operating golf carts shall observe and obey all rules
of traffic, state laws, federal laws, and city ordinances.



   (B)   A person shall not operate a golf cart in a reckless or
dangerous manner.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.07  SEATING.



   (A)   Golf carts shall be equipped with factory seating for all
occupants, with only one person seated in each seat.



   (B)   All persons in the golf cart shall remain seated at all times
the golf cart is operated.



   (C)   Children under the age of three years shall not be permitted
to ride on the golf cart.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.08  EQUIPMENT.



   Golf carts shall be equipped with headlamps, front and rear turn signal
lamps, tail lamps, stop lamps, brakes, seat belts on rear seats, a rear-view
mirror, and a triangular slow moving vehicle emblem mounted at the rear of
the golf cart and as near as practicable to the center of mass and at an
approximate height not less than three feet and not more than five feet from
level ground or pavement surface.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.09  OPERATION DURING SPECIAL EVENTS.



   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety may designate special
events, such as the annual Hot Dog Festival, in which golf carts may be
operated in compliance with this chapter with exceptions.



   (B)   If the golf cart used during special events does not meet the
requirements of § 79.08, the permitted hours as outlined in § 79.03 shall
be daylight hours only.



   (C)   During such special events, a registration fee of $10 per golf
cart used shall be paid to the city through the City Police Department for
deposit into the Police Equipment Fund. Such special event registrations
shall be valid for a period not to exceed one week.



   (D)   All other requirements and terms of this chapter shall apply.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 79.99



§ 79.10  EXEMPTIONS.



   The Frankfort Utility Service Department, the Street Department, and
the Public Safety entities are exempt from the provisions of the chapter.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)



§ 79.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall, upon a first finding of such violation, be subject to a fine not to
exceed $50, and upon a second or subsequent finding of such violation, be
subject to a fine not to exceed $100.



   (B)   Additionally, or alternatively, any operator of a golf cart
found to have committed a moving traffic offense as defined under state law,
shall be subject to fines and court costs as established by the State of
Indiana.



   (C)   Each violation shall constitute a separate offense and be
subject to a separate fine.



   (D)   If two or more violations of this chapter occur within the
same calendar year with respect to either an operator or a particular golf
cart, the registration of the golf cart involved in the most recent violation
shall be suspended and the owner or operator of the golf cart shall not be
eligible for another registration for a period of one year from the date of
such most recent violation.



(Ord. 12-04A, passed 4-9-12)
