LESS THAN 500 GPM




 



      (2)   Hydrant threads.  Open clockwise or right, close
counter clockwise or left National Fire Thread.



      (3)   Sprinkler connection.  Will be remote from building
unless otherwise authorized by the Fire Department Chief and the installation
will be subject to approval and inspection by the authority having
jurisdiction.  The sprinkler hook up will be Stortz one-quarter turn
connection, four inches in diameter,  with the following conditions:



         (a)   Must be accessible and unobstructed;



         (b)   Connection shall be three to five inches above
finish grade level (see figure below).



         (c)   Shall be turned downward at a 45 degree angle (see
figure below).



   [No figure provided to codifier.]



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.117  FIRE HYDRANTS.



   (A)   All private fire hydrants and water mains shall be installed
and maintained as set forth in the most recent edition of NFPA Standard No.
24. The Fire Inspector, in determining location and spacing of hydrants,
shall use Appendix C as a guide.



   (B)   The proposed location of private fire hydrants to supply the
required fire flow shall be approved by the servicing Fire Department prior
to construction of any Class 1 structure.



   (C)   Whenever the provisions of this chapter require the
installation of a fire hydrant; whether on public or private property, such
hydrant shall meet the following specifications:



      (1)   It shall be equipped with a five and one-quarter inch
main valve opening;



      (2)   It shall be constructed with two two and one-half inch
hose nozzles, and shall be National Standard Thread (NST).



      (3)    It shall be equipped with one four and one-half inch
steamer nozzle with six “V” threads per inch;



      (4)   It shall be constructed to be opened by turning
clockwise a National Standard Pentagon Operating Nut;



      (5)   The source of water supply shall be buried a minimum of
five feet below the ground level at the hydrant; and



      (6)   The hydrant shall be constructed with a break-off
feature to prevent the hydrant from leaking when damaged by collision.



   (D)   Nonfunctional hydrants shall not be located within 20 feet of
any waterline easement.



   (E)   All privately owned fire hydrants shall be painted red.



   (F)   Only approved hydrant wrenches shall be used to open or close
a fire hydrant.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.118  MARKING OF FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT, FIRE HYDRANTS AND ACCESS
ROADS.



   (A)   Fire protection equipment and fire hydrants shall be clearly
identified in a manner approved by the servicing Fire Department to prevent
obstruction by parking and other obstructions.



   (B)   Fire access roads shall be identified as fire lanes and the
provisions set forth in this section  shall apply.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.119  FIRE PROTECTION IN RECREATIONAL VEHICLES, MOBILE HOMES AND
MANUFACTURED HOUSING PARKS, SALE AND STORAGE LOTS.



   Recreational vehicle, mobile home and manufactured housing parks, sales
lots and storage lots, hereafter constructed or added to, shall provide and
maintain fire hydrants and access roads in accordance with 675 IAC 22, §§
902 and 903.



(CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see §
93.999



§ 93.120  SMOKE DETECTOR REQUIREMENTS FOR DWELLING UNITS.



   (A)   A SMOKE DETECTOR shall be defined for the purposes of this
section as a device, which detects visible or invisible products of
combustion.



   (B)   Each smoke detector shall detect abnormal quantities of smoke
and products of combustion that can occur in a dwelling, shall properly
operate in the normal environmental conditions of a household, and shall be
in compliance with ANSI/US 268 - Standard for Safety Smoke Detectors for Fire
Protective Signaling Systems, or ANSI/US 217-Standard for Safety Single and
Multiple Station Smoke Detectors.



   (C)   All dwelling units within the city shall be equipped with a
minimum of one functional, properly located, labeled and listed smoke
detector as described in NFPA Standard No. 72. Smoke detectors shall be
installed outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of
the bedrooms and on each additional story of the family living unit,
including basements and excluding crawl spaces and unfinished attics. In
family living units with one or more split-levels where there is an
intervening door between one level and the adjacent lower level, a smoke
detector shall be installed on the lower level. In new construction, a smoke
detector also shall be installed in each sleeping room, where more than one
smoke detector is required; detectors shall be arranged so that operation of
any smoke detector causes the alarm in all smoke detectors within the
dwelling to sound.



   (D)   All equipment shall be installed in accordance with the
manufacturer’s installation requirements and recommendations. If the method
of installation is not specified by the manufacturer, the smoke detector
shall be installed on the ceiling at least four inches from the wall or on a
wall with the top of the detector not less than four inches nor more than 12
inches below the ceiling. Smoke detectors in rooms with ceiling slopes
greater than one foot in eight feet horizontally shall be located at the high
side of the room.



   (E)   Smoke detectors required by 676 IAC 13 or 675 IAC 14 shall
have power supply as specified by the respective code. All other residential
smoke detectors may be powered by an AC power source or a battery. If the
detector is solely AC powered and the manufacturer does not supply
installation specifications, it shall be directly attached to a junction box
with power supplied either from a dedicated branch circuit or the unswitched
portion of a branch circuit also used for power and lighting, such
installation shall be in accordance with 675 IAC 17.



   (F)   Where smoke alarms exist in dwelling units, the warranty for
the alarm shall be with the manufacturer.



   (G)   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or remove
any smoke detector, except when it is necessary for maintenance or inspection
purposes. Any smoke detector removed for repair, replacement or local
remodeling shall be reinstalled or replaced so that it is in place and
operable.



      (1)   Rental dwelling units. Each owner or manager or rental
agent of the owner is responsible for the installation of required smoke
detectors and the repair or replacement of a required smoke detector within
two business days after the owner, manager or rental agent is given written
notification of the need to repair or replace the smoke detector. Residents
shall inspect and test the smoke detectors at least monthly and replace the
battery if necessary in accordance with manufacturer’s instructions.



      (2)   Owner dwelling units. Each owner is responsible for the
installation of required smoke detectors and the repair or replacement of a
required smoke detector within two business days of finding it inoperable. An
owner shall inspect and test the smoke detectors for power in accordance with
manufacturer’s instructions at least monthly.



   (H)   A person, company, or corporation violating I.C. 22-11-18-3.5
or I.C. 32-31-7-5 or the provisions of this section shall be subject to
penalties as specified in I.C. 12-8. Each day such violation is permitted to
continue may be deemed to constitute a separate offense, provided however the
aggregate penalty for any violation shall not exceed $2,500.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.121  MEANS OF EGRESS ILLUMINATION AND SIGNS.



   (A)   Means of egress illumination shall be provided and maintained
in accordance with 676 IAC 13. Means of egress shall be illuminated and exit
signs shall be maintained when the building or structure is occupied.



   (B)   Any replacement of exit signs in existing buildings or
structures or installation of additional exit signs shall meet the
requirements of 675 IAC 12-4-9.



   (C)   Equipment providing emergency power for means of egress
illumination and exit signs shall be maintained in an operable condition.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.122  EXIT DOORS, STAIRWAYS AND ELEVATOR SIGNS.



   (A)   Exit doors shall be readily distinguishable from adjacent
construction and shall be easily recognizable as an exit door. Exit doors
shall be as set forth in the applicable rules of the Commission or its
predecessor agencies.



   (B)   Stairway identification signs shall be located at each floor
level in all buildings as set forth in the applicable rules of the Commission
or its predecessor agencies.



   (C)   Instructions for operation of elevators under fire and other
emergency conditions shall be as set forth in the applicable rules of the
Commission or its predecessor agencies.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.123  OBSTRUCTION OF THE MEANS OF EGRESS.



   (A)   Obstructions, including storage, shall not be placed in the
required width of a means of egress, except projections as allowed by the 675
IAC 13. Means of egress shall not be obstructed in any manner and shall
remain free of any material or matter where its presence would obstruct or
render the means of egress hazardous.



   (B)   Any member of a Police or Fire Department who shall discover
any fire escape or means of egress encumbered or obstructed in any manner
shall report such condition to the appropriate Fire Prevention Bureau and the
Bureau shall immediately notify the owner or occupant to remove such
encumbrance or obstacle.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.124  INSPECTION OF FIRE ESCAPES.



   Exterior fire escapes shall comply with the requirements as set forth
in 675 IAC 22. Certification by a professional engineer licensed in the state
to show compliance with this section shall be filed with the Fire Prevention
Division upon order of the Fire Prevention Chief having jurisdiction over the
premises.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.125  SMOKING.



   (A)   As used in this chapter, smoke and smoking mean and include
the carrying of a lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette or tobacco in any form.



   (B)   No person shall smoke or carry a lighted match or lighter
within eight inches of the entrance of the following locations:



      (1)   Public assemblies;



      (2)   Educational occupancies;



      (3)   Institutional occupancies;



      (4)   Retail selling establishments;



      (5)   Buildings, except residential occupancies, which contain
explosives or combustible materials, any of which would be thereby exposed to
ignition; or



      (6)   When the Fire Prevention Chief designates as a “NO
SMOKING AREA” because of the fire dangers which the smoking could cause.
Provided, however, the owner of the above-enumerated places may designate
areas where smoking is permissible if such smoking room or area has been
approved by the Fire Inspector.



   (C)   No person shall smoke in any elevator.



   (D)   The owner or occupant shall post approved “NO SMOKING”
signs in each building, structure, room or place in which smoking is
prohibited. Signs shall be conspicuously and suitably located and shall be
maintained. However, this division does not apply to buildings or structures
which are smoke-free environments and are posted as such at all public and
employee entrances, and where no visible evidence of prohibited smoking
exists within the building or structure.



   (E)   No person shall remove any legally required “NO SMOKING”
sign, or smoke in any areas where such signs are posted.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.126  UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS AND NOTIFICATION.



   Any person who supervises, manages, or directs the installation,
retrofitting, removal or closure of underground storage tanks shall notify
the appropriate Fire Prevention Division 14 days prior to commencement of
work; however, this requirement shall not apply on emergency repair work
where 14-day notification is not possible.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



EMERGENCY VEHICLE LANES



§ 93.135  INTENT.



   It is the intent of this subchapter to provide for open areas of lanes
for the purpose of unrestricted access to certain commercial properties by
the Fire and Police Departments of the city, the emergency medical services,
or other emergency services.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.136  EMERGENCY LANE STANDARDS.



   (A)   Any owner, lessee, or other person in possession or control of
private commercial property shall in accordance with this subchapter
establish emergency vehicle lanes upon their property.



   (B)   Any new commercial structures must establish emergency vehicle
lanes in accordance with this subchapter.  Furthermore, any renovation of an
existing commercial structure over 50% pursuant to the Uniform Building Code
shall be required to include the establishment of emergency lanes.



   (C)   The Chief of Police and/or Chief of the Fire Department after
approval by the Board of Public Works and Safety are authorized and required
to establish emergency vehicle lanes on private commercial property.  The
Chief shall determine the location of emergency vehicle lanes established
herein and shall notify the property owners affected thereby in writing,
together with a notation as to the number of signs necessary pursuant to
division (D) below to properly notify vehicle drivers of the existence and
location of emergency vehicle lanes.



   (D)   Emergency lanes shall be approximately 20 feet in width and
shall be marked with the appropriate  yellow marks or lines. Signs
designating the emergency lanes shall be marked “NO PARKING - EMERGENCY
LANE” and shall be placed at least every 50 feet along the curb or side of
building wherein the lanes are established. The signs shall be of such size
and marking as to conform to state law. It shall be the responsibility of the
owner of the commercial property to bear the cost of the signs and marking
for the emergency vehicle lanes.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.137  COMPLIANCE.



   The parking, stopping, or standing of any personal property including
motor vehicles, or any other means of obstructing fire lanes on private,
commercial property shall be prohibited. Any vehicle or other personal
property found to be obstructing a fire lane shall, with the consent of the
owner, lessee, or other person in possession or control of the real estate
where such an emergency vehicle lane has been established, be towed away or
removed. The owner of such personal property shall be responsible for all
tow-in charges and resulting storage charges, if any.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.138  ENFORCEMENT.



   To aid in the enforcement of this subchapter the Fire Chief and/or the
Police Chief shall obtain from each property owner, lessee, or person in
possession of property covered by this subchapter an affidavit granting
permission for and consent to towing away of any personal property which is
obstructing emergency vehicle lanes. The original affidavit shall be filed in
the Clerk-Treasurer’s office with copies on file in the Fire Chief’s and
Police Chief’s offices.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.139  EXCEPTIONS.



   Those vehicles displaying a state “disabled” or other
“disabled” identifying insignia or by the attesting officer’s certain
knowledge of the person in question being “disabled” or
“handicapped,” may occupy an emergency lane while loading or unloading.
All areas already established and marked as “HANDICAPPED PARKING” shall
remain as placed and marked, and shall not be moved or changed in any manner
as to conflict with the establishing of emergency lanes.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



FAIRS AND FESTIVALS/AMUSEMENT OPERATIONS



§ 93.150  TENTS, CANOPIES AND MEMBRANE STRUCTURES.



   (A)   Tents having an area of 200 square feet or greater shall
comply with Chapter 24 of the Indiana Fire Code.



   (B)   Canopies with rigid frames used by vendors shall be anchored
by not less than 40 pounds of ballast on each leg of the structure. Ballast
can be sandbags, formed concrete anchors, concrete blocks, and the like,
fixed securely to the frame or leg of the structure. Anchoring with screws or
driven rods into the ground or paved surface is prohibited.



   (C)   Any cooking process that utilizes an open flame, creates
sparks or grease laden vapors is prohibited inside tents, canopies and
membrane structures.



   (D)   Any cooking process that grease laden vapors will require a
portable “K” class (potassium acetate wet chemical) fire extinguisher on
site.



   (E)   Compressed gas cylinders shall be secured in an upright
position that will prevent them from falling or being caused to fall over.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.151  HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENTS DEFINED.



   As used in this subchapter, HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENT means haunted house,
house of horrors, or any other activity in which persons are invited, guided,
escorted, or otherwise transported through a building or structure or portion
of a building or structure, temporary or permanent, for the purposes of
entertainment or amusement.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.152  PERMIT APPLICATION; PERMIT AND FEES REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall operate a Halloween amusement without first
obtaining a permit from the appropriate Fire Prevention Division.



   (B)   An application for a Halloween amusement permit shall be
obtained from the appropriate Fire Prevention Bureau and shall contain the
following information.



      (1)   The name of the organization sponsoring the amusement;



      (2)   The name of person(s) in charge of the amusement
operations; and



      (3)   The period of time (dates and hours) in which the
amusement will be operated.



   (C)   The fee for each permit issued pursuant to this section shall
be $25 payable to the appropriate Fire Prevention Bureau.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.153  AMUSEMENT INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   The authorized representative of the Fire Prevention Division
shall inspect the building or structure and the Halloween amusement as often
as may be reasonably necessary for compliance with applicable fire and life
safety requirements for its intended occupancy.



   (B)   Such inspections shall occur at the start of amusement
construction, at permit issuance and during permit period.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.154  PERMIT ISSUANCE AND TRANSFERABILITY.



   (A)   A Halloween amusement permit shall be issued only after the
appropriate Fire Prevention Division has had an opportunity to inspect the
subject premises, and has found that the building or structure and amusement
conforms with all applicable fire and life safety requirements as set forth
in 675 IAC 22 and this chapter.



   (B)   A permit issued pursuant to this section shall not be
transferable, and any change in use or occupancy of premises shall require a
new permit.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.155  APPEAL FROM DENIAL OF PERMIT.



   When the appropriate Fire Prevention Division shall reject or refuse to
grant a permit required by this  subchapter, or when it is claimed that
provisions of this section or any other provision of this code relating
thereto do not apply, the person may appeal from the decision in writing set
forth in this chapter.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.156  PERMIT PERIOD.



   Each permit granted under the provisions of this subchapter shall be
for such period as indicated on the permit and permit application; however,
any such permit shall expire 30 days after issued, of the year in which it is
issued.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.157  DISPLAY OF PERMIT REQUIRED.



   A permit issued pursuant to this subchapter shall at all times be in a
conspicuous place on the premises designated in the permit and shall at all
times be subject to inspection by anyone duly authorized by the Fire or
Police Department.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



FIRE REPORTING SYSTEMS



§ 93.170  SCOPE OF DIVISION.



   The division shall cover installation and maintenance of all manual and
automatic fire alarm systems in new and existing buildings. Also, faulty
and/or false alarms, and delayed notification of manual or automatic systems.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.171  MONITORING OF FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS.



   Fire alarms systems required by the rules of the Commission or its
predecessor agencies shall be monitored as set forth in such rules.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.172  NOTIFICATION UPON FIRE ALARM ACTIVATION.



   (A)   The Fire Department shall be notified upon the activation of
any alarm, except in a supervised fire drill or periodic testing of system.



   (B)   Notwithstanding division (A), such notice shall be required if
the alarm is directly transmitted by private line or automatic dialer to the
Fire Department.



   (C)   The monitoring company shall notify the Fire Department
immediately when the alarm is received at all times except as stated in
division (A).



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.173  FAULTY ALARMS.



   (A)   Whenever a Fire Department responds to an automatic fire alarm
or medical alarm at a premise or building more than three times in a 90-day
period due to improper alarm installation, lack of maintenance, servicing, or
failure to notify the Fire Department of a drill or test, a service charge
shall be imposed.



   (B)   For a fourth response in a 90-day period, the service charge
shall be $75, for a fifth response in a 90-day period, the service charge
shall be $100, and for the sixth and subsequent responses in a 90-day period,
the service charge shall be $150.



   (C)   Such service charges shall be payable to the Fire Department.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



FIREWORKS



§ 93.180  DEFINITIONS.



   For purposes of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CONSUMER FIREWORK.  As defined in I.C. 22-11-14-1, as amended.



   FIREWORK.  As defined in I.C. 22-11-14-1, as amended.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.181  CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE AND ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   Fireworks and the temporary storage, use handling of
pyrotechnic special effects material used in motion pictures, television, and
theatrical and group entertainment productions shall be in accordance with
I.C. 22-11-14 and 675 IAC 22.



   (B)   A certificate of insurance conditioned for the payment of all
damages which may be caused either to a person or persons in an amount of not
less than $100,000, and to property in an amount of not less than $100,000,
by reason of the licensed display, arising from any acts of the licensee, his
or her agents, employees or subcontractors.



   (C)   A questionnaire that is available at Frankfort Fire
Headquarters must be filled out in its entirety and reviewed before approval
of a permit for a public display of fireworks.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful to conduct a public display of fireworks
prior to complying with these requirements.



(Ord. CO-03-05, passed 8-25-03; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.182  SALES OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS.



   (A)   A questionnaire that is available at Frankfort Fire
Headquarters must be filled out in its entirety and reviewed before approval
of a permit for the sale of consumer fireworks.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any consumer
fireworks prior to complying with these requirements.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.183  RESTRICTIONS AS TO DATES AND TIMES.



   Consumer fireworks may only be used or discharged within the City of
Frankfort, Indiana, on the following dates and times, as provided in I.C.
22-11-14-10.5:



   (A)   Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. on June 29, June
30, July 1, July 2, July 3, July 5, July 6 and July 7;



   (B)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on July 4;
and



   (C)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m.
on January 1.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.184  RESTRICTIONS AS TO LOCATION.



   Consumer fireworks may not be used or discharged in any city park or on
any other property owned or occupied by the city and may be used or
discharged only as follows:



   (A)   On the property of the purchaser of the consumer fireworks;



   (B)   On the property of another who has given permission to use the
consumer fireworks; or



   (C)   At a special discharge location designated by the Fire Chief
in accordance with rules adopted by the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building
Safety Commission.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty,
see § 93.999



§ 93.185  ENFORCEMENT.



   The Fire Chief of the city, or his or her designee, or the Police
Department is responsible for the interpretation and civil enforcement of
this subchapter.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



§ 93.186  SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS.



   Enforcement personnel from the Fire Department or the Police Department
may seize and dispose of consumer fireworks that are used in violation of
this subchapter.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



PROHIBITED ACTS



§ 93.195  FALSE ALARMS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to give or cause to be
given any false alarm of fire in the city.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.196  DRIVING OVER FIRE HOSE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any automobile, truck,
trailer, railroad car, or other vehicle over or to permit such vehicle to
drive over, any hose belonging to the Fire Department while the hose is laid
in the streets of the city during time of fire, or the practice of the Fire
Department of the city, or when such hose is laid in the streets of the city
for any other purpose.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.197  FOLLOWING EMERGENCY VEHICLES TOO CLOSELY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motorized vehicle in
such a manner as to be following an emergency vehicle at a distance of less
than 300 feet, while the emergency vehicle is responding to an emergency call.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.198  FAILURE TO YIELD.



   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a vehicle to fail to
yield the right of way to an emergency vehicle that has its lights and siren
operating while responding to an emergency call.



(Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)  Penalty, see § 93.999



§ 93.999  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which a penalty is
not otherwise provided shall be fined not more than $250. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. CO-07-11, passed 8-20-07; Am. Ord. 14-08, passed 8-11-14)



CHAPTER 94:  SKATEBOARD PARK



Section



   94.01   Requirements



§ 94.01  REQUIREMENTS.



   The following requirements shall apply to all parks, facilities or
improvements owned, maintained, operated or situated on property owned by the
city for use by skateboarders and inline skaters:



   (A)   The city recommends that any person using the skateboard park,
which is located on property owned by the city, wear elbow pads, knee pads,
wrist pads and a helmet that meets the standard of either the American
Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) or the United States Consumer
Product Safety Commission (CPSC) or standards established by these entities
subsequent to the adoption of this section.



   (B)   Any child or children 12 years of age or under who are using
the skateboard park shall be supervised by an adult.



   (C)   Use of bicycles in the skateboard park is prohibited.



   (D)   Any person using the skateboard park must wear shoes at all
times while in the skateboard park.



   (E)   It shall be a violation of this section for any person to
create graffiti in or upon the skateboard park improvements or to engage in
tagging or the use of accelerants or wax.



   (F)   It shall be a violation of this section for any person in the
skateboard park to use profanity or to engage in horseplay, roughhousing,
violence or any potential dangerous activity.



   (G)   Alcoholic beverages, tobacco products, firearms or weapons of
any kind are expressly forbidden in the skateboard park on city-owned
property.



   (H)   No skating shall be permitted on surfaces containing water,
snow or ice. Further, it shall be a violation of this section for any person
to cause salt or sand to be applied to the skateboard park facility or to use
any means whatsoever for removal of snow or ice from the facility.



   (I)   No person shall use, enter, or be on a skateboard park outside
of the hours of operation posted in the skateboard park.



   (J)   No person shall use, enter, be on or remain in the skateboard
park after having been notified by the Superintendent of the Parks Department
or by the Frankfort Police Department that they must leave the skateboard
park or that they are barred from use of the skateboard park as a result of
an unsafe use of the skateboard park, or failure or refusal to obey the rules
pertaining to the park's use.



   (K)   No person shall enter or exit the skateboard park by any means
other than by walking through a gate, turnstile, door, or other means
provided and intended by the city for ingress or egress into the skateboard
park.



   (L)   No person at, in or on the skateboard park shall violate any
rule or regulation developed and adopted by the Superintendent of the Parks
Department and posted on signs at the skateboard park or any other applicable
rule established by this section.



   (M)   Any person determined by the Chief of Police of the City of
Frankfort or his or her authorized designee to have been in violation of
divisions (C) through (K), above, shall be subject to citation for an
infraction and shall be subject to a fine of $25 for a first violation and
$50 for a second or any subsequent violation.  Violators shall be cited to
the Frankfort City Court for adjudication of their citation.  In addition to
or in lieu of any fine, provided for herein, the Chief of Police of the city
or his or her authorized designee may temporarily or permanently bar the
violator from using the skateboard park for any violation of divisions (C)
through (K), above, or for violation of any rule provided for under division
(L), above.



   (N)   The parent or legal guardian having control or custody of an
un-emancipated minor whose conduct violates this section shall be jointly and
severally liable with the minor for the amount of any fine and court costs
imposed pursuant to this section.



(Ord. 06-19, passed 7-10-06)



CHAPTER 95:  NOISE CONTROL



Section



   95.01   Definitions



   95.02   Vehicle noise limits



   95.03   Excessive noise by vehicles



   95.04   Exemptions



   95.05   Violations; procedure



   95.06   Evidence of excessive noise in criminal prosecution



 



   95.99   Penalty



§ 95.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   A-WEIGHTED SOUND LEVEL.  The sound pressure level in decibles as
measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network.  The level so
read is designated db (A) or dbA.



   DECIBEL (db).  This means a unit of sound pressure measurement as
defined by the American National Standards Institute bulletin.



   LIGHT MOTOR VEHICLES.  Any automobile, van, motorcycle, motor-driven
cycle, motor scooter, dune buggy, snowmobile, all-terrain vehicles, go-carts,
minibikes, trail bikes, or trucks with gross vehicular  weight of less than
8,000 pounds.



   MODIFIED AND DEFECTIVE EXHAUST SYSTEMS.  An exhaust system in which
the original noise abatement devices have been physically altered causing
them to be less effective in reducing noise or the original noise abatement
devices have either been removed or replaced by noise abatement devices which
are not as effective in reducing noise as their original devices, or devices
have been added to the original noise abatement devices such that noise
levels are increased.



   NOISE LEVEL.  The A-weighted sound level produced by a motor vehicle.



   SOUND LEVEL METER.  An instrument which includes a microphone,
amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output meter, and
weighting networks used to measure sound pressure levels.  The instrument
shall be used for measurement of the intensity of sound and calibrated in
decibels as standardized by the American Standard Association.  Readings
shall be made on a db (A) scale.



   TRAFFIC NOISE.  Sound made by a motor vehicle operated either on the
public right-of-way or private property.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)



§ 95.02  VEHICLE NOISE LIMITS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause noise levels from the
operation or use of light motor vehicles in excess of 80 db (A) in any area
within the corporate limits of the city, at any time.  The noise level limit
shall be measured on a distance of not less than 15 feet from the noise
source.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.03  EXCESSIVE NOISE BY VEHICLES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to operate, or
use a light motor vehicle such as to cause excessive noise levels as a result
of a defective or modified exhaust system, or as a result of unnecessary
rapid acceleration, deceleration, revving or tire squeal, or as a result of
the operation of audio devices such as but not limited to radios,
phonographs, and tape players on or from the vehicle.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)  Penalty, see § 95.99



Cross-reference:



   Unnecessary vehicle noise in drive-in restaurants or on private parking
lots prohibited, see § 131.29



§ 95.04  EXEMPTIONS.



   The following are exempted from the provisions of this chapter.



   (A)   Sound emitted from sirens of authorized emergency vehicles.



   (B)   Lawnmowers, garden tractors, and similar home power tools when
properly muffled.



   (C)   Burglar alarms on light motor vehicles of the electronic
signaling type which transmit an audible signal to a receiver which can be
carried by the owner or operator of the vehicle.



   (D)   Celebrations on Halloween and legal holidays and celebrations
in connection with duly authorized parades.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)



§ 95.05  VIOLATIONS; PROCEDURE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this
chapter.  Whenever any police officer makes an arrest for violation of this
chapter he shall take down the name, address, operator's license number, and
registration number of the vehicle of the alleged violator in writing on the
form provided by the Police Department, a citation for a violation of this
chapter.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.06  EVIDENCE OF EXCESSIVE NOISE IN CRIMINAL PROSECUTION.



   In any criminal prosecution for a violation of this chapter, the court
may admit evidence of a noise level as tested by a sound level meter which
meets or exceeds the American National Standards Institute (AMSI)
specifications or type II equipment.  A person shall be found guilty of
violation of this chapter for the emission of the excessive noise from or on
any motor vehicle source in excess of the limitations established herein.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)



§ 95.99  PENALTY.



   Any person upon conviction of a violation of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $500.



(Ord. PO-81-1, passed 5-11-81)



CHAPTER 96:  NUISANCES



Section



General Provisions



   96.01   Definitions



   96.02   Buildings unfit for habitation



   96.03   Open, uncovered pits or cellars



   96.04   Accumulations of junk or litter



   96.05   Machinery, refrigerators accessible to public



   96.06   Loud, unnecessary, or unusual noise



   96.07   Abatement



Junk Cars



   96.15   Abandoned or junk vehicles as a nuisance; with exceptions



   96.16   Removal from private property



   96.17   Removal from public property



Noxious Weeds



   96.25   Growth prohibited



   96.26   Violation notice



   96.27   City to abate



   96.28   Continuous abatement



   96.29   Appeal of costs



   96.30   Filing of lien; penalties



Code Enforcement Officers



   96.40   Enforcement violation



 



   96.99   Penalty



Cross-reference:



   Loud or odorous animals, see § 90.04



   Non-maintained or odorous privies, septic tanks, and the like, see §
51.006



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 96.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ABANDONED VEHICLE and JUNK VEHICLE.



      (1)   A vehicle located on public property illegally.



      (2)   A vehicle left on public property continuously without
being moved for three days.



      (3)   A vehicle located on public property in such a manner as
to constitute a hazard or obstruction to the movement of pedestrian or
vehicle traffic on a public right-of-way.



      (4)   A vehicle that has remained on private property without
the consent of the owner, or person in control, of that property, for more
than 48 hours.



      (5)   A vehicle from which there has been removed the engine,
transmission, or differential or that is otherwise partially dismantled or
inoperable and left on public property.



      (6)   A vehicle that has been removed by a towing service or a
public agency upon request of an officer enforcing a statute or ordinance
other than this chapter, if the vehicle once impounded is not claimed or
redeemed by the owner or his agent within 15 days of its removal.



      (7)   A vehicle that is six or more model years old and
mechanically inoperable, and is left on private property continuously in a
location visible from public property for more than 30 days.



(I.C. 9-9-1.1-2)



   PUBLIC NUISANCE.  Any condition found to exist upon any public or
private property within the corporate limits of the city, which is a danger
to the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
PUBLIC NUISANCES shall include but not be limited to those nuisances
enumerated in the following sections of this chapter. ('75 Code, §  42.01)



§ 96.02  BUILDINGS UNFIT FOR HABITATION.



   Any building or part of a building which by reason of its lack of
repair, unsanitary condition, its being infested with rats, vermin, or
insects, or which for any reason is unfit for human habitation or constitutes
a source of danger to the health and safety of the inhabitants of this city,
shall constitute a public nuisance and shall be unlawful as such.



('75 Code, §  42.03)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.03  OPEN, UNCOVERED PITS OR CELLARS.



   Open or uncovered cellars, cisterns, pits, wells, or vaults shall
constitute a public nuisance and be unlawful as such.



('75 Code, §  42.04)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.04  ACCUMULATIONS OF JUNK OR LITTER.



   All accumulations of brush, junk, litter, rubbish, tin cans, or trash
of any kind shall constitute a public nuisance and shall be unlawful as such.



('75 Code, §  42.05)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.05  MACHINERY, REFRIGERATORS ACCESSIBLE TO PUBLIC.



   Any machinery not connected with the operation of a household or
business; or any equipment, including but not limited to refrigerators or
freezers, with doors intact; in any open or unfenced area, or in any building
or structure to which the public has access, shall constitute a public
nuisance and shall be unlawful as such.



('75 Code, §  42.06)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.06  LOUD, UNNECESSARY, OR UNUSUAL NOISE.



   The making or continuing, or the causing or aiding to be made or
continued, of any loud, unnecessary, or unusual noises which either annoy,
injure, or endanger the comfort, repose, health, or safety of others, unless
the making or continuing of the noise is justified or necessary to protect
life or property, shall constitute a public nuisance and shall be unlawful as
such.



('75 Code, §  42.07)  Penalty, see § 96.99



Cross-reference:



   Loud or excessively noisy animals as public nuisance, see § 90.04



§ 96.07  ABATEMENT.



   (A)   Whenever any nuisance shall be found to exist upon any public
or private property within the city, the Chief of Police or the Building
Inspector of the city shall issue an order to the person maintaining the
nuisance or to the owner or occupant of the premises to abate the nuisance
within three days if upon public property or ten days if upon private
property.  If any person, firm, or corporation so notified shall neglect,
fail, or refuse to comply with the requirements of the order by abating the
nuisance within the specified time, the person, firm, or corporation shall be
punishable under§ 96.99.



   (B)   In the event of refusal or neglect of the notified offender to
obey the order and abate the nuisance as ordered, the Chief of Police or the
Building Inspector shall have the unlawful condition abated.  The costs and
expenses of the abatement shall be a lien upon the real estate of the person
maintaining the nuisance, and shall be placed on the tax duplicates by the
auditor and collected as taxes are collected.



('75 Code, § 42.17)



JUNK CARS



§ 96.15  ABANDONED OR JUNK VEHICLES AS A NUISANCE; WITH EXCEPTIONS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or allow to remain in the
open, on public or private property within the city, any disassembled, or
unoperable and unlicensed, or any junked, wrecked, or abandoned motor vehicle
for a period of five days on public property or a period of ten days on
private property, unless it is in connection with an automotive sales or
repair business enterprise which operates under duly issued and exhibited
store license and is located in the properly zoned area.



(Ord. CO-92-5, passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 96.99



Statutory reference:



   Abandoned vehicles, see I.C. 9-22-1 et seq.



§ 96.16  REMOVAL FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY.



   Whenever the Frankfort City Engineer or City Police Officer shall find
any such vehicle placed or stored in the open upon private property within
the city, he or she shall issue an order to the owner of said vehicle to
remove said vehicle within ten days.  Notice of such order shall be placed
upon the vehicle and copies of the notice will be served upon the owner of
said vehicle or any adult occupying the real estate on which the vehicle is
located, if his or her whereabouts is unknown.  If no owner or occupant of
the real estate of the vehicle can be located, a notice affixed to any
building on the real estate shall constitute notice to the owner or the
occupant of the real estate and to the owner of the vehicle.  If there is no
building on the real estate, the notice may be affixed elsewhere on the real
estate.  If the vehicle is not removed within ten days pursuant to such
order and notice, and if the order is not stayed by the issuing officer
pursuant to a written request showing good cause for permanent or temporary
stay, the City Engineer or City Police Officer shall cause the vehicle to be
removed by a junk or salvage yard or wrecker service. The cost and expense of
such removal to be paid by the owner of said vehicle.  The owner of said
vehicle will be issued a ticket into Frankfort City Court for violation of
said order.



(Ord. CO-92-5, passed 2-10-92)



§ 96.17  REMOVAL FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY.



   Whenever the Frankfort City Engineer or City Police Officer shall find
any such vehicle placed or stored in the open upon public property within the
city, he or she shall issue an order to the owner of the vehicle to remove
within three days.  Notice of such order shall be placed upon the vehicle. 
If such vehicle is not removed within three days pursuant to such order and
notice, the City Engineer or City Police Officer shall cause the vehicle
removed by a junk or salvage yard or wrecker service, the cost and expense to
be paid by the owner of the vehicle.  The owner of said vehicle would also
be cited into Frankfort City Court for violation of said order.



(Ord. CO-92-5, passed 2-10-92)



NOXIOUS WEEDS



§ 96.25  GROWTH PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any lot, parcel or tract
of real estate located within the corporate limits of the city to allow,
cause or permit the excessive growth of grass or the growth of weeds or other
rank vegetation, or the excessive accumulation of any such substances, in or
upon any portion of such lots, parcels or tracts of real estate.



   (B)   (1)   For purposes of this subchapter, the term WEEDS OR
OTHER RANK VEGETATION shall include, but not be limited to the following
weeds exceeding seven inches in height: Canada Thistle, Field Bindweed,
Johnson Grass and Sorghum Almum, Perennial Peppergrass, Perennial Sowthistle,
Quackgrass, Russian Knapweed, Wild Garlic and Wild Onion, Bitter Wintercress,
Buckhorn, Cocklebur, Corncockle, Curley Dock, Dodder, Eastern Black
Nightshade, Field Peppergrass, Giant Foxtail, Horsenettle, Mustard, Oxeyed
Daisy, and Pennycress.



      (2)   The term WEEDS OR OTHER RANK VEGETATION shall also
include grass exceeding seven inches in height, but shall not include
agricultural crops such as hay and pasture.



('75 Code, § 42.12)  (Ord. 177, passed 9-l-64; Am. Ord. CO-06-15, passed
6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.26  VIOLATION NOTICE.



   In the event of a violation of § 96.25, the City Building Inspector or
the Superintendent of the Frankfort Street Department, or their respective
designees, shall issue a written notice (“violation notice”) to the owner
of record of the real estate at the address most recently shown in the tax
records of the Office of the Clinton County Auditor.  If there are multiple
owners of the property, such notice shall be sent to at least one of such
owners of the property. If the tax records reflect an address different from
the street address of the property in question, then a written notice may
also be delivered to or mailed by ordinary mail to the occupant or tenant of
the property at the street address of the property. The violation notice
shall identify the violation and order the landowner to correct the same
within ten days from the date the notice is served. Notice shall be
considered served when delivered to or when delivery has been attempted at
the owner’s address.



(Ord. CO-06-15, passed 6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12)



§ 96.27  CITY TO ABATE.



   If the landowner fails to timely abate each violation set forth in a
violation notice, employees of the city or the city’s agents or independent
mowing contractors, may enter upon the real property for the purpose of
mowing, cutting or removing the grass, weeds or other vegetative
substances.  In such case, the city shall prepare a statement or invoice as
to its costs and expenses incurred in taking such action and shall mail the
statement or invoice by ordinary mail to the landowner at the owner’s
address as used in § 96.26.  The landowner shall within 30 days from date
of such mailing pay the amount shown on the invoice to the Clerk-Treasurer of
the city. Any property owner who disputes the violation notice may appeal the
notice by filing a written notice of appeal with the Building Inspector at
301 E. Clinton Street, Frankfort, Indiana, no later than five days after such
notice is served. Any appeal shall be heard before the Board of Public Works
and Safety of the city.



(Ord. CO-06-15, passed 6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12)



§ 96.28  CONTINUOUS ABATEMENT.



   If an initial violation notice was provided by certified mail or
equivalent service under § 96.26, a continuous abatement notice may be
posted at the property at the time of abatement instead of by certified mail
or equivalent service as required under § 96.26. A continuous abatement
notice serves as notice to the real property owner that each subsequent
violation during the same year for which the initial notice of the violation
was provided may be abated by the city.



(Am. Ord. CO-06-15, passed 6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12) 
Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.29  APPEAL OF COSTS.



   Any invoice or statement issued pursuant to § 96.27 or § 96.28 of
this subchapter may be appealed to the Board of Public Works and Safety if
written notice of appeal is filed with the Clerk-Treasurer of the city within
14 calendar days after the statement or invoice has been mailed to the
landowner.  In such event of appeal, the city shall notify the owner of the
place, date and time of the hearing on appeal before the Board.



(Ord. CO-06-15, passed 6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12)



§ 96.30  FILING OF LIEN; PENALTIES.



   If any statement or invoice for mowing or removal is not paid within
the 30 days provided for in §§ 96.27 and 96.28, the city may certify the
charge or charges and cause the same to be recorded as a lien in the Clinton
County records and to have them placed on the tax duplicate in the Office of
the Clinton County Auditor to be collected as taxes and disbursed to the
general fund of the city.  In addition, any property owner determined to be
in violation of this subchapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in
§ 96.99.



(Ord. CO-06-15, passed 6-26-06; Am. Ord. 12-09, passed 9-10-12)



CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS



§ 96.40  ENFORCEMENT VIOLATION.



   It shall be unlawful and a violation of the municipal code for any
person, firm, corporation or organization to intentionally interfere with any
Code Enforcement Official in the carrying our of such official's enforcement
duties under this subchapter.  For the purpose of this section, the term
"Code Enforcement Official" shall mean and include any employee of the city
who is authorized by the city to enforce the provisions of this subchapter
and is acting within the scope of his or her employment.



(Ord. 06-9, passed 2-13-06)  Penalty, see § 96.99



Cross-reference:



   Provisions concerning interference with city officials, see § 131.02



§ 96.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person, firm, or corporation who shall violate a provision
of this chapter for which another penalty is not provided, shall upon
conviction thereof, be subject to a fine as follows:



      (1)   For a first offense, the fine shall be not less than
$100 nor more than $250, together with court costs, as determined by the
court.



      (2)   For a second offense of the same nature and occurring on
the same property, and within 24 months of a first offense, the fine shall be
not less than $250 nor more than $500, together with court costs, as
determined by the court.



      (3)   For the third offense of the same nature and occurring
on the same property and within 24 months of the second of such offense, the
fine shall be not less than $500 nor more than $2,500, together with court
costs, as determined by the court.



   (B)   For purposes of this section as to penalties, each day that a
violation continues after due notice has been served, shall constitute a
separate offense and each motor vehicle shall constitute a separate
offense.  ('75 Code, §  42.16)  (Ord. 177, passed 9-1-64; Am. Ord. 06-7,
passed 2-13-06)



   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any of the
provisions of §§ 96.15 through 96.17, or who interferes in any way with the
due process of enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, or who
does not obey within the time fixed any order issued pursuant to §§ 96.16
or 96.17 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $10 nor more than
$500.  Each motor vehicle shall constitute a separate offense and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation
occurs or continues.  ('75 Code, §  42.15)  (Ord. 184, passed 2-1-66)



(Ord. PO-77-2, passed 12-21-77)



CHAPTER 97:  STREETS AND SIDEWALKS



Section



General Provisions



   97.01   Ice, snow, or dirt accumulations



   97.02   Building materials on streets or sidewalks



   97.03   Erection of poles or posts



   97.04   Vehicles or animals on pavement



   97.05   Tree-trimming requirements



Excavations
